summary: Paul Merson reignited his feud with Andros Townsend following the Tottenham midfielder's brief appearance in a 0-0 draw with Burnley. Merson, who earlier criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, was proven wrong when Townsend scored for England against Italy. Despite acknowledging his mistake, Merson mocked Townsend's seven-minute cameo in the Tottenham match via Twitter. Townsend had previously responded to Merson's criticism after scoring against Italy, questioning Merson's opinion of his abilities. The latest incident suggests that the tension between the two has not fully dissipated.

Chelsea has made a formal offer for FC Tokyo's 22-year-old forward, Yoshinori Muto, as confirmed by FC Tokyo's president, Naoki Ogane. If the move is completed this summer, Muto will join Chelsea's partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, on loan for the next season. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps and one goal, would be the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea. He has an impressive record with FC Tokyo, scoring 16 goals in 37 appearances. Recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, Muto is considering the offer but has not made a decision yet. The potential transfer is not linked to Chelsea's sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber. A £4 million deal has been suggested for the player.

A large-scale study has found that babies administered antibiotics within the first six months of life have a higher likelihood of being overweight as toddlers. Finnish researchers, publishing in the journal Pediatrics, suggest that antibiotics, which are known to promote weight gain in farm animals, may have a similar effect on children, potentially contributing to the obesity epidemic. The study, which analyzed the weight and height of over 12,000 two-year-olds alongside records of antibiotic prescriptions, revealed that by the age of two, one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese, with those who had taken antibiotics as infants being particularly at risk. Repeated antibiotic use before the age of two further increased the odds of obesity. Boys appeared more susceptible to weight gain after antibiotic use and were also slightly taller. While the study did not definitively prove causation, it hypothesized that antibiotics might kill gut bacteria that would otherwise consume some of the food, thus making more food available for the body to absorb, and could also increase appetite. The lead author, Dr. Antti Saari, emphasized the potential role of early antibiotic exposure in the childhood obesity epidemic and the importance of judicious antibiotic use in infancy. The study adds to growing concerns about the over-prescription of antibiotics and its consequences on health.

A Buckingham Palace guard experienced an embarrassing incident during the Changing of the Guard ceremony, slipping on a manhole cover and falling in front of numerous tourists. The guard lost his balance, hitting his bearskin hat and dropping his rifle. The incident was captured on camera by a tourist, David Meadwell, who was visiting London with his family. Despite the fall, the guard quickly got up as his colleagues continued marching, and he appeared to blush upon realizing the number of onlookers. The soldier is believed to have slipped due to metal protectors on his boot soles. The Changing of the Guard is a popular event, drawing large crowds daily in the summer and every other day in the winter. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

A&E Networks is set to remake the iconic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and drew over 100 million viewers. The remake, scheduled for 2016, will be simulcast across A&E, Lifetime, and History. LeVar Burton, who played Kunta Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce the new version, which aims to be more faithful to Alex Haley's novel and will consult with African and African-American history scholars for authenticity. The remake seeks to engage both fans of the original and a new generation unfamiliar with the story. Executive producer Mark Wolper, whose father produced the original, sees the project as a continuation of Kunta Kinte's story through the generations. The new "Roots" arrives in a cultural context that includes the presidency of Barack Obama, the success of "12 Years a Slave," and ongoing racial issues in the U.S.

The passage details the allegations made by Christopher Lawler, a former royal footman, who claims that he was subjected to an attempted sexual assault by palace aides on his first day working at Clarence House in 1978. Lawler, now 64, states that he was pinned to a chair and groped by a male staff member. The incident left him so distressed that he left the job the same day. Despite his attempts to report the incident, his complaints were ignored for months until the police were eventually notified. Lawler, who was 27 at the time of the incident, was working at Clarence House when it was the residence of the Queen Mother. He was accosted by several men, one of whom was a senior staff member, who attempted to undress him. After managing to escape, Lawler was followed and threatened to remain silent. His initial complaint was met with an angry response from Clarence House, prompting him to leave immediately. Haunted by the incident for years, Lawler decided to contact palace officials again in 2014, following inquiries into alleged cover-ups of child sex abuse by a VIP paedophile ring in the 1970s and 80s. His complaint was initially rebuffed twice before being passed to Scotland Yard months later. A retired royal aide in his 80s was interviewed but denied involvement, citing his presence at Balmoral working for the Queen at the time. Lawler has since been informed that the Royal Household will cooperate fully with any police investigation. The police have declined to comment further as investigations are ongoing.

An Oregon couple, Jesse and Melissa Meek, announced their pregnancy through a rap video parodying the theme song from the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, which has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube, features the couple rapping about their journey to parenthood while driving in a car. Melissa mentions realizing she was late for her period and discovering the positive pregnancy test, while Jesse notes their surprise at conceiving within two months. The video concludes with the couple sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. The Meeks told KPTV that the video was made to inform distant loved ones about the baby, and its popularity was unexpected. Another video is planned for when they find out the baby's gender. Melissa had previously made a video capturing Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy news, which he discovered through a tag on their dog indicating a baby was on the way.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film Gone With the Wind was auctioned for $137,000. The ensemble, consisting of a gray jacket and skirt with black zigzag applique, was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned by Heritage Auctions in Beverly Hills, California. The dress, originally slate blue-gray, has faded to light gray over time. It was owned by James Tumblin, a former Universal Studios hair and makeup department head, who collected on-screen costumes, props, and behind-the-scenes artifacts from the film since the 1960s. Tumblin saved the dress from disposal in the 1960s, purchasing it for $20. Other high-selling items included a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, Clark Gable's trousers and jacket for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. Gone With the Wind, based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel, celebrated its 75th anniversary the previous year, and Hattie McDaniel, who played Mammy, became the first African-American actor to win an Academy Award for her role in the film.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo when his mother, holding him and another child, lost her grip and he slipped into the pit. The incident occurred on a Saturday around 3 pm, with the child falling between 10 to 12 feet. The boy was rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center with minor bumps and bruises and was listed in stable condition. The child's leg was injured in the fall, but he was not attacked by the cheetahs. Zoo officials and witnesses suggest the child was dangled over the railing, leading to the fall. The zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetahs did not approach the boy or his parents while they were in the pit, possibly due to fear or curiosity. The exhibit was closed following the incident.

A non-functional speed camera, which had been enforcing a 30mph speed limit in Handsworth, Birmingham, has been repositioned to face a residential house. The camera, along with about 300 others using outdated technology, was deactivated in the West Midlands in 2013. Since then, speed enforcement has been handled by mobile units, motorway cameras, and traffic officers. The reason for the camera's reorientation is unknown, but Birmingham City Council is aware of the situation and plans to visit the site, potentially removing the camera. The council has no plans to include this camera in a pilot program for new digital technology. The homeowners have not commented on the issue.

The Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association has announced that Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3. Bolt confirmed his participation, stating he is fit, healthy, and ready to run as part of the Jamaican team. He expressed excitement about the event's atmosphere and Jamaica's tradition in relays, promising to make the country proud. The JAAA General Secretary, Garth Gayle, expressed pleasure at Bolt's availability, anticipating 'sprint magic' at the event. The full Jamaican team list for the competition will be announced later.

Neymar and Dani Alves, Barcelona football players, showed support for their club's basketball team by attending El Clasico, a Euro League contest, where Barcelona won 85-80 against Real Madrid. They were accompanied by Neymar's sister, Rafaella. Despite the win, Real Madrid leads the Euro League division by points difference. Neymar had recently helped Brazil win against Chile 1-0 in a match at the Emirates Stadium, where he faced tough challenges. Barcelona, under Luis Enrique, had won their El Clasico match before the international break, leading La Liga by four points. Neymar and the team are set to face Celta Vigo upon their return to La Liga, as they aim for a treble of trophies.

The passage discusses the escalating issue of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, leading to a significant strain on Italy. From Friday to Monday, the Italian coast guard rescued 8,480 migrants, and on Monday alone, they received distress calls from 20 boats. There are fears that 400 migrants could be missing after a ship carrying 550 people reportedly capsized in the Mediterranean, about 80 miles off the Libyan coast. However, the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident and has not found any evidence to support it. There has been a notable increase in migrant boats crossing the Mediterranean into Italy, with over 10,000 migrants registered in the first three months of 2015. Most of these migrants come from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit country. At least 480 migrants have died this year while attempting the crossing, often due to bad weather and unsafe conditions on smugglers' vessels.

Arsene Wenger, Arsenal's manager, is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose Arsenal over Liverpool, although he is unsure of the exact reasons for Sanchez's decision. Sanchez, who was sought after by several top clubs after Barcelona decided to let him go, was convinced to join Arsenal by Wenger. The Chilean forward has made a significant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals in his debut season. Wenger acknowledges that Liverpool's interest in Sanchez could have been used as leverage during negotiations for Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. Despite this, Sanchez's choice to join Arsenal for £32 million has been a positive for the team. Wenger praises Sanchez's qualities, including his efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit, which have helped revitalize the team and supporters. Ahead of a crucial Premier League match against Liverpool, Wenger downplays rumors of a potential transfer move for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling. He also commends Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for developing the team well, particularly after the departure of Suarez and the injury to Daniel Sturridge.

Here is a summary of the passage:

- Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome.
- The event will take place at the Lee Valley VeloPark, and Wiggins views the hour record as a significant challenge in cycling, having been pursued by some of the sport's greatest names for over a century.
- Wiggins aims to inspire others to challenge themselves and encourages people to ride their bikes and see how far they can go in an hour.
- He is expected to set a record that could last for some time and hopes for a capacity crowd of 6,000, with tickets going on sale from April 19.
- The current record of 52.491km was set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February, following reforms in regulations by the UCI, which reignited interest in the event.
- Wiggins recently finished his Team Sky career and will ride in the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire before preparing for the Hour record attempt.
- He is targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics in the four-man, four-kilometre team pursuit.
- British cyclist Alex Dowsett will also attempt to break the record on May 2 in Manchester.

Here is a concise summary of the passage, covering the core pieces of information described:

- Serena Williams, a two-time French Open champion, described her hard-fought victory over Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an 'eye-opener' for the claycourt season.
- Williams, the world No 1, won against Errani with a score of 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, maintaining an 8-0 career record over her.
- The US team was defeated 3-2, with Williams and Alison Riske losing the doubles match 6-0, 6-3 to Errani and Flavia Pennetta, resulting in their relegation to World Group II.
- Williams acknowledged that she is not as prepared for the claycourt season as she thought, indicating she needs to adjust her playing style from hard court.
- Despite winning her 19th singles grand slam at the Australian Open, Williams' performance highlighted the need for improvement on clay, her least successful surface.
- US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for the team to work harder, with the goal of regaining their position among the elite nations in the World Group next year.

River Plate, the Argentine football club, is interested in signing Radamel Falcao, the Manchester United striker, although they acknowledge that a deal would be complex. Falcao, who previously spent eight years with River Plate before moving to Porto in 2009, is welcomed to return, according to vice president Matias Patanian. Despite Falcao's underperformance during his loan at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals, he has shown good form for Colombia, equaling their all-time goalscoring record. Having joined River Plate at 15 and scoring 34 goals in 90 appearances, the club is open to his return.

X Factor finalist and pop star Ella Henderson, aged 19, has become the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. The campaign features Henderson showcasing various hairstyles against a vibrant city background. Images include her hair worn down in a wavy style and in a tousled half-ponytail. The partnership between the platinum award-winning artist and the UK's number 1 dry shampoo brand was facilitated by the MILES agency. The campaign launched with a TV advertising campaign featuring Henderson's latest single, "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed her excitement about working with the brand, which she uses regularly. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, commented on the natural synergy between the artist and the brand, anticipating an exciting 2015.

The family and friends of Aaron Siler, who was shot dead by police officer Pablo Torres in Kenosha, Wisconsin, last month, are shocked and upset by a billboard erected in the city featuring Torres and his dog. The billboard, paid for by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, reads 'Thank you for your support, Kenosha,' which Siler's family and friends interpret as disrespectful, especially to Siler's mother. They are calling for the billboard to be taken down. The police association claims the billboard was intended to thank the community for its support following recent incidents, including the shooting of Siler and another incident where Torres shot a suicidal man armed with two knives. The investigation into Siler's shooting continues, while the shooting of the suicidal man was deemed justified.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the border with Pakistan. The incident occurred in the southeastern town of Negur, and three of the militants were also killed by Iranian forces. The militants reportedly crossed into Iran from Pakistan. Iranian officials have asked Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving assailants. A militant group called Jaish al Adal claimed responsibility for the attack. This group is an anti-Iranian organization that has emerged in areas of Balochistan, a Pakistani province bordering southeastern Iran. The group, which is Sunni Muslim, targets Shiites and aims to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan. Jaish al Adal has previously claimed responsibility for attacks on Iranian territory, including one in October 2013 where 14 Iranian border guards were killed. Iranian authorities have criticized Pakistan for not controlling the terrorists effectively. The Pakistani government condemned the attack as an act of terrorism and stated that security agencies are investigating the incident and have requested any evidence from Iranian authorities. If the militants entered Pakistan after the attack, they will be apprehended and brought to justice.

The passage discusses a recent political conversation in Japan regarding UFOs and extraterrestrial encounters. Defense Minister Gen Nakatani assured the Diet, Japan's parliament, that the Air Self Defense Force (ASDF) has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO. This response was given in reply to a question from Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler turned lawmaker, who asked if ASDF jets had ever been scrambled to meet extraterrestrial threats and if research was being conducted on alien visitors. Nakatani stated that while the ASDF sometimes encounters birds or other flying objects, there has been no case of finding an object believed to have come from outside Earth. Inoki, known for his wrestling career and various political and diplomatic endeavors, claims to have seen a UFO himself but is unsure if aliens exist. This is not the first time Japanese politicians have discussed extraterrestrial visitors; in 2007, then-Defense Minister Shigeru Ishiba considered the legal implications of defending against a space invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger, Jin Pai, at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in China was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after the toilet he was squatting on broke and shattered. Jin was reportedly standing on the toilet rim due to cleanliness concerns when it tipped over and broke, injuring him. He contacted his companions for help but was too injured for anything other than immediate medical attention. Authorities took him to a hospital in Hefei where he received several dozen stitches. Jin initially confessed to squatting but later claimed he was sitting to possibly avoid compensation. The police considered the incident an accident and reminded the public that toilets are for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old man from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested following allegations of sexual abuse and invasion of privacy. The case came to light when a 15-year-old girl discovered a hidden camera in her bathroom. Rebbie is accused of abusing the girl over a four-year period and recording her and others using a hidden camera. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault, unlawful contact with a minor, sexual abuse of children, and invasion of privacy. Investigators found 41 videos from the hidden camera, 34 of which showed victims showering, with some footage focusing on children's genitalia. Rebbie admitted to filming multiple victims, including other juveniles. The preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, and Rebbie is held on a $500,000 bail. The nature of Rebbie's relationship with the girl's family is not disclosed.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama has created a series of portraits featuring fathers leaping into the air alongside their poised, smiling daughters. The images are part of Aoyama's latest book, titled "Daughter and Salary Man," which showcases fathers, typically dressed in formal suits, expressing their fun side through dramatic jumps, while their daughters look on calmly. The series aims to capture the excitement and hope of the fathers, allowing them to break from their serious demeanor. The photos have garnered online interest for their unique and humorous concept, with the families posing in various locations across Japan. Despite the lack of detailed information about the project, the images have become popular for their quirky nature.

The passage discusses the dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and its implications for Kevin Pietersen's potential return to the England cricket team. Pietersen, appearing in a range of emotions from deep thought to joviality, is seen in the Surrey team photo ahead of the county championship season. His last international appearance was during the disastrous Ashes tour in Australia. With Downton's sacking, Pietersen's return to the international set-up becomes more likely as he rejoins Surrey, aiming to force his way back into the Test team. England is looking to regain the Ashes urn this summer, and Pietersen's participation could be crucial. The passage also describes Pietersen's interactions with photographers and team members during the photo session, highlighting his cheerful demeanor.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, has dismissed Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially fired on Wednesday due to poor performance, he was briefly reinstated the next day when owner Angelo Massone decided to give the coaching staff another chance. However, after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani, Massone was again displeased, leading to Ze Maria's final dismissal. The former Brazil defender, who has 25 international caps, will be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic. Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt currently stands 16th in the league, six points from safety. Ze Maria, who replaced Florin Marin in January, was the club's third coach this season.

Nabil Dirar, a former teammate of Radamel Falcao at Monaco, thinks Falcao might regret his loan move to Manchester United, despite his discontent in France. Falcao, who previously played for Atletico Madrid, joined Manchester United on a season-long loan but has not performed as well as he did before a significant knee injury. Manchester United would have to pay £46 million to permanently sign Falcao, but with only four goals scored in the season, it's unlikely they will proceed with the purchase. Dirar suggests that Falcao might have been better off staying at Monaco, where he could have played more and been involved in the Champions League.

A man wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt robbed a Christchurch dairy, escaping with the till and approximately $1500 in cash. The incident occurred on Saturday at the Union St dairy in east Christchurch around 12:30 pm. The robber, described as very tall, frightened the owner's daughter who was working at the time, causing her to scream 'robber!' and run out of the shop. The man threw the cash register to the ground, took the till drawer, and fled. No weapons were used in the robbery. New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify the robber and have asked anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers or message police online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for having inappropriate relationships with underage students. Initially arrested on March 19 for an alleged sexual encounter with a 15-year-old student, she was released on bail. Granado was arrested again after another 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him on two consecutive nights in January. The incidents reportedly took place in her car near another school in Dallas. Granado admitted to kissing the first student and allowing him to touch her breasts in April the previous year. She was suspended from teaching and placed on administrative leave. Despite initial beliefs that there were no other victims, a second student came forward, leading to Granado's second arrest. She was booked into Irving County Jail and released after posting a $50,000 bail. Her plea to the second set of charges is unknown. The Irving school district assured families that they took immediate and appropriate action against Granado.

A video has garnered over 500,000 views online, depicting a large crocodile swimming through a public marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws. The incident occurred when the dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, approached the water's edge and was caught by the crocodile. New Zealander Tim Weston, who was on holiday in the area, witnessed the event and described the crocodile holding onto the dog for an extended period. The crocodile sanctuary nearby and the natural habitat of the mangroves in Puerto Vallarta mean that crocodile sightings are not uncommon. The video has elicited shock and horror from social media users.

Steve Bruce, Hull City's manager, is confident in his team's ability to avoid relegation from the Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, which has left them in a precarious position. Initially aiming for 10 wins to secure survival, Bruce now hopes that "nine or eight might be enough." Hull had a stronger first half against Southampton but conceded a penalty scored by James Ward-Prowse and a late goal from Graziano Pelle. With six games left, including tough matches against Liverpool, Arsenal, Tottenham, and Manchester United, Bruce remains optimistic, stating that his team is up for the challenge and that they can secure the necessary results. He attributes their struggles partly to long-term injuries to key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Southampton's win, meanwhile, moved them up to fifth place, but their manager, Ronald Koeman, faced issues with player discipline when Sadio Mane attempted to take the penalty instead of Ward-Prowse, leading to a team discussion about rule adherence.

A teacher, Ian Guffick, has been banned from teaching for at least two years after allowing pupils to change their answers on SATs exams and altering some answers himself at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury. This action led to the invalidation of the entire school's SATs results for 2014. Guffick was forced to resign and admitted to the unacceptable professional conduct, although he claimed he only asked students to make answers more legible. The National College for Teaching and Leadership's panel found that no changes should be made to exam scripts outside of test conditions. Guffick was given 28 days to appeal the decision to the High Court.

The passage discusses Anders Lindegaard, a Danish international goalkeeper for Manchester United, who, despite limited playing time at the club, enjoys a fulfilling personal life. He is married to Misse Beqiri, a Swedish model with Albanian roots, whom he wed in a beach wedding in Mauritius. The couple, who started dating in 2012 and have a son together, often share their moments on Instagram, showcasing their life and Beqiri's modeling work. Lindegaard, who moved to Manchester United in 2010, has made only 19 league appearances in five seasons, finding himself third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes. Despite interest from FC Midtjylland, a transfer did not materialize due to disagreement over price. Lindegaard's career at Manchester United has been overshadowed by his personal successes.

The 13 glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium failed to sell at a Sotheby's auction, despite estimates of $300,000 to $600,000. The only bid, $260,000, came from a Sotheby's employee. The letters, owned by Yankee Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson since 2008, had been a fixture at the stadium since 1976. Jackson, who attended the auction, had hoped to pass the "icon of the Yankees and of New York City" to a new generation. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers has addressed the recent controversial behavior of Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe, reminding them of their professional responsibilities. Sterling was caught inhaling nitrous oxide, a legal high, and both players were pictured with shisha pipes. Despite this, Rodgers has not disciplined the players and aims to move past the incident. He emphasizes the importance of understanding the limitations and responsibilities that come with being professional athletes. Steven Gerrard, who is available after a three-match suspension, may or may not be recalled for the FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa, as Rodgers focuses on leading Liverpool to their first FA Cup final of his tenure. Rodgers also reflects on the team's past near-misses, suggesting that such experiences are part of the journey to success.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil, after returning from international duty where he helped Germany win against Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier, shared a photo on Twitter showing him relaxing at home with his dog. Despite missing Arsenal's last match against Newcastle due to illness, Ozil is anticipated to play in the upcoming game against Liverpool. There were rumors of him being seen at a Berlin nightclub post the Newcastle game, but these were dismissed by Arsenal's manager, Arsene Wenger. Ozil has been performing well since his return from injury, contributing four assists and scoring three goals since January. He also mentioned that he is now well-adjusted to English football, stating that the demanding schedule suits him perfectly as he prefers playing in numerous matches.

Barcelona's president, Josep Maria Bartomeu, has stated that the club has no intentions of replacing coach Luis Enrique, who took over last summer with a two-year deal. Despite rumors of Enrique's replacement, Bartomeu affirmed the club's satisfaction with Enrique's performance, noting his dedication and hard work, particularly in preparation for crucial matches. Enrique's contract extends until 2016, and the club is pleased with his tenure, as Barcelona remains in contention for three major trophies late in the season. This was evidenced by their recent victory over Valencia, with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi, keeping them on track for potential title wins.

Jordan Henderson has agreed to a new long-term contract with Liverpool, providing a boost after their FA Cup disappointment. The contract, expected to be signed soon, will reportedly be worth around £100,000 per week and extend until 2020. Henderson, 24, is the third key player to extend his contract under Brendan Rodgers, following Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Since joining Liverpool in 2011 from Sunderland, Henderson has significantly improved under Rodgers and is considered for the captaincy role after Steven Gerrard's departure. Meanwhile, contract talks with Raheem Sterling are on hold until the end of the season.

Filipe Luis, a full back for Chelsea, has expressed his desire to remain at the club until the end of his contract, despite Atletico Madrid's interest in re-signing him. Luis, who moved from Atletico Madrid to Chelsea last July, has found it challenging to secure the left back position at Stamford Bridge. However, he is content at Chelsea and intends to stay. Recently, Luis played for Brazil in friendlies against France and Chile during the international break. As the Premier League title run-in approaches, Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho is ensuring the team remains focused and committed to winning every game, acknowledging the difficulty of the upcoming matches but expressing confidence in the team's preparedness.

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps No 8 player, had his three-match ban overturned on appeal after he was initially suspended for accidentally knocking out George North during a game on March 27. Hughes was initially deemed 'reckless' for not preventing his knee from colliding with North's head as he scored a try for Northampton, resulting in a red card and subsequent suspension. Despite no intent to harm, Hughes missed his club's Champions Cup quarter-final loss against Toulon. The ban was criticized by many, including Wasps captain James Haskell and fly-half Andy Goode, who found the decision hard to understand given the accidental nature of the incident. Former England player Austin Healey and Harlequins captain Joe Marler also condemned the ban. Following the appeal, Hughes' ban was rescinded, allowing him to return to action immediately, although he was not included in the match-day squad for Wasps’ Aviva Premiership trip to London Welsh. The appeal panel concluded that no act of foul play occurred, as the incident was accidental.

The passage describes a phenomenon where fiery, intensely red sunsets were observed in Seattle, Washington, due to wildfires in southeastern Siberia. The wildfires, initially started by farmers burning grass, grew out of control on April 14th because of strong winds, leading to the destruction of dozens of villages. Although the fires were eventually extinguished, the smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting areas in Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The smoke particles filtered out shorter wavelength colors from sunlight, such as greens, blues, yellows, and purples, allowing red and orange hues to dominate the sky, especially during sunrises and sunsets when light travels through more atmosphere. As the smoke dissipates, the air quality will improve, and the sunsets will lose their reddish color.

Becky Schoenig, a resident of St. Louis, Missouri, experienced the theft of her brand new 2015 Ford Fusion just over a month after purchasing it. The car was stolen from her driveway on a Monday night. On April 1, Schoenig was informed by the police that her car had been found, thanks to a tip from a man who recognized it as hers. Upon the car's return, Schoenig discovered that it had been modified with new red rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Instead of being upset, she expressed gratitude to the thieves on Facebook, joking that her car was now "pimped out." However, she also mentioned the need to professionally clean the car due to a strong smell of cigarettes and marijuana. Schoenig plans to honor Mick Sexton, the man who helped locate her car, by creating a smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot. The smoothie will include banana, pineapple, peach, and coconut cream. Schoenig is described by a friend as a vibrant and happy person who enjoys making others laugh.

Manchester City players stand to lose £500,000 each in bonuses if the team does not qualify for the Champions League this season. This is due to incentivised contracts designed to comply with financial fair play rules. The team's European hopes are uncertain after losing to Manchester United in the Manchester derby. City, currently in fourth place, could be overtaken by Liverpool, who are four points behind. The top three Premier League teams qualify directly for the Champions League, with the fourth-placed team needing to win a qualifying round. Approximately £12 million in bonuses for the City squad is contingent on achieving their European target. Manager Manuel Pellegrini acknowledges that the team's performance has deteriorated, particularly after seven losses in 2015. The team's struggle may impact their ability to sign high-profile players like Paul Pogba. Manchester United, now four points ahead of City, is also interested in Pogba and is confident in attracting top talent in the upcoming transfer window.

In the 'mini-derby' between Manchester United and Manchester City's Under 18 teams, United emerged victorious with a 1-0 win, courtesy of Callum Gribbin's free-kick. The match, held at Altrincham's Moss Lane, saw free entry and attracted nearly 1,000 spectators. Notably, 13 out of the 22 players were English, with 10 being from Manchester. United's coach, Paul McGuinness, employed a three-at-the-back formation, similar to the first team's strategy. Gribbin, who had previously gained internet fame for his skills against Aston Villa, was the standout player. Despite City's efforts, including a near-goal from Marcus Wood and a late attempt by Javairo Dilrosun, United secured the win. The victory keeps United in contention for the league title, two points behind leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City suffered their second loss in the play-off series. The match showcased promising young talents from both sides, potentially deserving of first-team opportunities.

Joe Hart, the England goalkeeper, celebrated his 50th cap for his country by praising Italian counterpart Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game'. Hart's milestone came in a 1-1 draw with Italy, the same match in which Buffon earned his 147th cap. Hart, who is 10 years younger than Buffon, expressed his admiration for the Italian's longevity and skill, stating he is still learning from watching Buffon. Hart also expressed his desire to continue adding to his own cap count, aiming to play well for both his club, Manchester City, and his country.

Mexican restaurant chain Chipotle is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery services for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. This move comes after the company had previously declined offers from third-party delivery services. The service will include a nine percent service charge, with delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Postmates uses independent contractors who drive their own cars, similar to Uber's model. Chipotle's decision follows the trend of other franchises like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King, which are also exploring or expanding their delivery services. The passage also mentions that political figures like Marco Rubio and Hillary Clinton have been spotted dining at Chipotle, highlighting the chain's popularity.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the Boston Marathon bombings, have written an op-ed in The Boston Globe urging the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as a sentence for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, convicted on all 30 charges related to the bombings. Bill and Denise Richard propose that Tsarnaev should instead serve life in prison without the possibility of release and waive all rights to appeal. They argue that pursuing the death penalty could lead to years of appeals, forcing their family to relive the traumatic event. The Richards lost their 8-year-old son and had their 7-year-old daughter severely injured in the bombings. They believe it is time to end the anguish and look toward a better future for their family, Boston, and the country.

The passage describes a custom-built Boeing 747-8 that has been converted into a luxury private jet for an undisclosed billionaire. The jet, which typically could carry up to 600 passengers, has been redesigned over three years at an estimated cost of £400 million to accommodate the owner's specifications. Features include a dining room, kitchen, lounge, state room, an 'aeroloft' with eight beds, a master bedroom, a conference room, and spaces akin to luxury hotel rooms. The interior design is opulent, with porthole-style windows, plush furnishings, and amenities suitable for both business and relaxation, making it one of the most extravagant private planes ever constructed.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

1. SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying an uncrewed Dragon spacecraft to the International Space Station (ISS) from Cape Canaveral, Florida.
2. The attempt to land the rocket stage on a floating barge was unsuccessful, with the rocket landing too hard for survival.
3. SpaceX founder Elon Musk tweeted about the landing, clarifying that the rocket tipped over after landing.
4. SpaceX had previously attempted to land a Falcon 9 on a drone ship in January, but the rocket hit at an angle and exploded.
5. The goal of landing the rocket is to reduce costs by reusing rockets, similar to airplanes.
6. The top part of the rocket will carry the Dragon into orbit, break away, and burn up in Earth's atmosphere.
7. The Dragon will dock with the ISS to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker.
8. The ISS crew will spend about five weeks unpacking the Dragon and then fill it with over 3,000 pounds of experiments, trash, and other items to return to Earth.
9. This is the sixth SpaceX mission to the ISS, and the company was the first private space contractor to dock with the station.
10. The launch was the second attempt for this mission, with the first attempt scrubbed due to weather.

Priscilla Presley is set to witness the first wedding at the newly established Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, an event resulting from a contest launched by NBC's Today show for an Elvis-obsessed couple to win the 'ultimate wedding'. The winning couple, to be announced on Monday, will marry on April 23 at the chapel located inside the Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton, where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a hotel suite for two nights, airfares, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla Presley has insisted that the event is first-class and not a joke, with no impersonators allowed. She has been involved in the design of the chapel, which is part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit outside of Memphis, Tennessee. Couples vying for the wedding must submit a video or photos explaining why they deserve the prize.

Liverpool's vice-captain, Jordan Henderson, believes his team can catch Manchester City in the Premier League after a 2-0 win over Newcastle United. This victory was significant as it came after disappointing results against Manchester United and Arsenal. Henderson, along with goalkeeper Simon Mignolet, played their 47th game of the season in this match, matching a record for appearances in the top European leagues. Despite being four points behind Manchester City, Henderson is optimistic about closing the gap, especially as City has shown weaknesses. Raheem Sterling scored the first goal with skillful play, followed by Joe Allen's first Anfield goal, capitalizing on a defensive error. Allen acknowledged that the win was crucial after recent defeats and admitted that Liverpool benefited from a potential missed penalty call when Dejan Lovren seemed to foul Ayoze Perez. The team is determined to keep winning and putting pressure on Manchester City in the race for the Champions League.

Roma ended their four-month winless streak at home by defeating Napoli in a crucial Serie A match, impacting Champions League placements. Miralem Pjanic scored in the 25th minute following a counter-attack, and Morgan de Sanctis made multiple saves to secure the win. This victory was significant for Roma, as it was their first home win in seven matches since November 30. The win moved Roma four points ahead of Lazio, provisionally, while Napoli's winless streak extended to five matches, keeping them in fifth place. Security was heightened due to past incidents involving Napoli fans, but the match proceeded without major incidents. Despite missing key players like Francesco Totti and Gervinho, Roma managed to secure the victory, with De Sanctis playing a crucial role in denying Napoli's attempts to equalize.

Doncaster Rovers, experiencing a lackluster season resulting in mid-table positioning in League One, faced Fleetwood Town in a match that failed to excite, given Fleetwood's diminished playoff prospects. The game ended in a 0-0 draw, presenting a challenge for Doncaster's media team in creating engaging match highlights. Consequently, they produced a brief 27-second video, with only 14 seconds of gameplay, encapsulating the kickoff, a goal kick, and the final whistle. This succinct summary was deemed a must-watch for football enthusiasts.

The passage describes a unique relationship between a man, Roland Giroux, and his blood parrot cichlid, a type of fish. Giroux has developed a bond with the fish to the point where he can gently hold and massage it, with the fish appearing to enjoy the interaction and actively returning to his hand after initially swimming away. The fish, which is a hybrid breed first bred in Taiwan in 1986, used to share its tank with two other fish but was bullied by them, leading Giroux to remove the others. The man regularly interacts with the fish, feeding it by hand and spending at least 15 minutes daily playing with it. The fish shows signs of wanting more attention if Giroux does not interact with it daily, and the video concludes with the fish following his hand to the water's surface as he removes it from the tank, suggesting a level of attachment or enjoyment from the interaction.

The passage discusses the character and management of Ben Stokes, a fiery and aggressive cricketer in the England team. It highlights an incident where Stokes broke his wrist by punching a locker, emphasizing the need for him to channel his aggression appropriately. Stokes has a reputation for not backing down, as seen in his confrontations with opponents like Marlon Samuels and Mitchell Johnson. England coach Peter Moores is noted for providing guidance on how Stokes should respond to such clashes, which Stokes handled well after a recent incident. The text advocates for a balance in managing Stokes, allowing his exuberance but controlling his aggression to ensure it contributes positively to the team's performance. There is a desire to have Stokes in the team regularly to help him reach his full potential, and the consideration of playing a second spinner, Adil Rashid, might affect his or Chris Jordan's place, though the preference is to have both play as much as possible.

The Euro 2016 qualifier match between Wales and Belgium, scheduled for June 12 at the Cardiff City Stadium, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are leading in Group B with 11 points each, and Wales' recent 3-0 victory over Israel has heightened hopes for their qualification to the 2016 finals in France. Despite the high demand, the match will not be moved to the larger Millennium Stadium due to UEFA rules and the preference of the Wales squad to play at the Cardiff City Stadium.

England's Under-17 football team, coached by John Peacock, is set to defend their UEFA European Under-17 Championship title in Bulgaria next month. The team, known as the Young Lions, qualified with a perfect record and will face Italy, Holland, and the Republic of Ireland in Group D. Their first match is against Italy on May 7. The squad includes talents from various Premier League clubs, such as Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, and Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold, who are returning after missing the Elite Round of qualifiers. Additional matches will be against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

The passage discusses Manchester City's interest in signing 14-year-old playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis from Anderlecht. Patoulidis is highly regarded as a top talent and has also caught the attention of Arsenal and Barcelona. He previously turned down a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to focus on his studies. Manchester City have engaged in discussions with Anderlecht's chairman, aiming to secure a compensation deal for the young player, as part of manager Manuel Pellegrini's strategy to invest in promising young talent.

A 33-year-old transgender escort, Vanessa Santillan, was found dead with head and neck injuries in a flat in Fulham, London. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed to return for further questioning. Santillan, a Mexican national, worked in London, Paris, and Miami. Scotland Yard is appealing for anyone who had contact with her before her death to come forward. The police are investigating the case and have not confirmed if her profession was central to the investigation. Santillan was pronounced dead at the scene when the London Ambulance Service was called on March 28. She had expressed her love for London and Paris on social media before her death.

The passage details a distressing incident where a woman, Dawn, who has experienced seven miscarriages, accuses her long-term friend Jamie of stealing money intended for a gravestone for her stillborn child, Daniel James. The theft came to light on The Jeremy Kyle show, where a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt. Jamie, a convicted burglar, initially denied the accusation but was later revealed to have confessed via a Facebook message, blaming his girlfriend Carol. Dawn, feeling betrayed, was left in tears and stormed off the show. The money, £207 of a planned £500, was crucial for Dawn and her partner, also named Jamie, to honor their child with a proper gravestone.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, mostly women, children, the ill, and elderly, after capturing and displacing them in northern Iraq. The release was facilitated by Arab tribal leaders, and the freed Yazidis were received by the Peshmerga force and taken to Irbil, the Kurdish regional capital. The exact reason for the release is unclear. This is not the first time ISIS has released Yazidis, previously freeing children and the elderly. ISIS' treatment of Yazidis has been brutal, including killings, rapes, and enslavement. The Yazidis, a minority group of Kurdish descent, follow a pre-Islamic religion and have faced persecution, including being labeled as devil worshipers. The international community responded to the crisis with aid drops, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS.

The passage highlights Harry Kane's successful season, noting his energetic celebrations on the field and his new animated appearance off the field in a video by Copa90. Kane, a Tottenham striker, has been nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards due to his impressive performance, including 20 Premier League goals. The animation features key moments from his season, such as goals against Chelsea and Arsenal, and his debut for England where he also scored. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', is released ahead of the awards ceremony where he competes against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the right leader for Liverpool, despite a season without trophies and a probable finish outside the top four. Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, argues that one's future shouldn't be determined by a single game. He acknowledges the challenges Liverpool faced with new players and believes they haven't fully integrated yet. Carragher emphasizes that Rodgers, the players, and staff should focus on the next season, aiming to win a trophy and secure a top-four spot. He stresses the importance of making the right signings, as they can significantly impact the team's performance. Carragher received a Beacon Award for his community work in Merseyside, where he has been coaching in schools in underprivileged areas through his 23 Foundation. He expresses his commitment to helping the community and inspiring young people to achieve their goals.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his plastic Nerf gun confiscated by security at East Midlands Airport before a flight to Lanzarote. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was deemed a security risk after being detected by X-ray machines. Security officers also frisked the child, a move criticized by his father, Phil Hayward, as "ludicrous" and "over-zealous." The airport later apologized for the inconvenience but cited government regulations that prohibit items resembling weapons. Upon returning from their holiday, James was given a replacement toy gun. The airport offered to return the confiscated toy to the family's home.

A man from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted an advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife with specific requirements. He describes his ideal partner as a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good at household chores, a good cook, and intimate. The successful candidate will receive free gym membership, a phone of their choice, and may be offered a company car, phone, and laptop. The man, who calls himself 'Rich', is 31 years old, athletic, white, tattooed, with brown hair and eyes, and does not drink, smoke, or do drugs. He is 175cm tall, well-endowed, owns properties, makes good money, loves cars, bikes, and outdoor activities, and is independent. He promises to be generous with his partner and will consider all reasonable offers, excluding former partners.

The passage discusses Football Association chairman Greg Dyke's proposal to increase the minimum number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12, a move supported by five former England managers: Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren. Dyke's plans also involve changing the definition of 'home-grown' players to those trained in England for three years before the age of 18, rather than 21. The former managers, in a letter to Dyke, urge the English game to support these changes, warning that failure to do so could further diminish England's standing in football and make it harder to win the World Cup. They highlight the shrinking pool of English talent playing at the top level as a disadvantage for the national team. The managers also note the emergence of young talents like Harry Kane as evidence that England can still produce top players, but argue that these players need more opportunities to play.

In the latest episode of the series, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, gives birth to a baby daughter, with Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, expressing his love and gratitude towards her. The pregnancy's timeline is notably compressed, with Demelza going from barely showing to being eight months pregnant within the span of one episode, and giving birth shortly after. This accelerated pregnancy timeline has been a point of amusement and discussion among fans, with comments on social media highlighting the unrealistic speed of pregnancies in the show. Despite the quick developments, Ross's affection for Demelza is clear, solidifying his commitment to her and their new family.

Leicester's manager, Nigel Pearson, is urging his team to stay focused and not get distracted by their relegation rivals. Despite being at the bottom of the Barclays Premier League, Leicester is only three points from safety after winning two matches in a row. Pearson emphasizes that their future is in their own hands and wants his team to concentrate on their own performance, not on external factors or other teams' results. He warns against over-optimism and stresses the importance of doing their own job well, especially as they host Swansea in an upcoming match.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest migration of a mammal ever recorded, swimming nearly 14,000 miles from her feeding ground off Russia's Sakhalin Island to Baja, Mexico. This journey surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale that swam 10,190 miles. Varvara's trip is significant as it indicates her ability to navigate across vast open waters and suggests that some western gray whales, an endangered species with only about 150 believed to exist, might actually be eastern grays. During her migration, she visited three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, leading scientists to speculate about her origin and the potential overlap between eastern and western gray whale populations.

A section of the seabed off the east coast of Japan's Hokkaido Island, near the town of Rausu, has risen to the surface, extending the coastline by 1,000 to 1,640 feet and reaching up to 50 feet above sea level in some areas. This unexpected emergence is believed to be the result of a landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which dropped a section of land and pivoted the underwater area upwards. The landmass, measuring about 100 feet wide, appeared overnight without any prior indication such as tremors or sounds, surprising the local residents. Geologists and local officials have confirmed the event is not related to the recent earthquake in Kathmandu and do not expect the landmass to expand further. Marine organisms, including seaweed and sea urchins, remain attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel has refuted rumors of his departure from Paris Saint-Germain, expressing his happiness and commitment to the club despite a recent conflict with coach Laurent Blanc over being benched for a Champions League match against Chelsea. Van der Wiel, who is fond of the club, city, and his teammates, has no intentions of leaving and is interested in renewing his contract. He respects Blanc's decisions regarding playing time and is prepared to play when needed. However, PSG's interest in Barcelona's Dani Alves could potentially affect Van der Wiel's future with the team.

Carlos Tevez is seeking to leave Juventus to rejoin his former club, Boca Juniors, in Argentina. Despite his contract with the Serie A champions extending until the end of the next season, Tevez has expressed his desire to depart this summer. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, has stated that the deal to bring the 31-year-old back is nearing completion, contingent on Tevez terminating his contract with Juventus first. Juventus, although reluctant to lose their top scorer, have acknowledged Tevez's wish to leave and are considering replacements. Tevez, who began his career at Boca Juniors, has always intended to conclude his career at the Argentine club. His potential move is not expected to affect his standing with the Argentina national team, as per his international manager, Tata Martino.

During Bayern Munich's Champions League match against Porto, which ended in a 6-1 victory for the home team, Bayern's manager, Pep Guardiola, experienced an embarrassing wardrobe malfunction. In the excitement of the game, Guardiola tore a hole in the left leg of his grey trousers, revealing his underwear. Despite the incident, Guardiola maintained a good sense of humor, joking that he would need to buy new trousers for the next match. The victory secured Bayern Munich's place in the Champions League semi-finals, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and a double from Robert Lewandowski. The win was particularly impressive given Porto's two-goal lead from the previous match. Guardiola's team demonstrated their superiority, leaving potential European rivals wary of their strength.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, resulted in injuries to ten people, including four children. The incident occurred on Wednesday afternoon. Two patients, a 40-year-old man with chest and shoulder injuries and a five-year-old boy with chest pain, were initially airlifted by rescue helicopter to the Princess Alexandra Hospital. Later, a 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also flown out. Six other individuals, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital for minor injuries or assessment. One person was trapped in their vehicle and was freed by Queensland Fire and Rescue using hydraulic cutting gear. The highway was closed with diversions in place, and it was expected to remain closed for a few hours.

Arsenal's Mesut Ozil has received a new Apple Watch, which he excitedly shared on Instagram, comparing it to Michael Knight's watch from the TV show Knight Rider. The Apple Watch, priced between £299 and £13,500, was obtained during a visit to an Apple store. Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is anticipated to play in the upcoming match against Chelsea. Arsenal is currently 10 points behind Chelsea with six league games left. Jack Wilshere's return from injury has bolstered Arsenal's lineup, and club legend Ray Parlour believes Wilshere's fitness is crucial for his potential impact on the team. Parlour, a three-time championship winner with Arsenal, sees Wilshere as the club's future if he can maintain fitness, noting the player's ability to go past opponents and link up with teammates. The concern, however, is Wilshere's history of injuries, similar to Abou Diaby's situation.

Referee Mark Clattenburg is set to officiate the Manchester derby between United and City, despite sending off three players from both teams earlier in the season. City's captain, Vincent Kompany, was recently dismissed by Clattenburg in an international match, resulting in his suspension for an upcoming game against Wales. Clattenburg has faced accusations of favoring United manager Louis van Gaal's team, but this season, he has sent off only two players in the Premier League, both from United. The referee, known for some controversial decisions but recognized as one of the Premier League's top officials, will be joined by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official. The derby, crucial for determining the team that finishes second behind Chelsea, sees United, who have won their last five league games, slightly ahead of City in the standings.

Bob Katter, a federal MP for Kennedy, has criticized the Queensland Government, suggesting they viewed MP Billy Gordon as 'a little black puppet on a string,' expecting him to resign after allegations of domestic violence and revelations about his criminal past. Katter, who has faced racism from major parties due to his Lebanese descent, empathizes with Gordon's situation. Gordon, who left the Queensland Labor Party, decided to remain in parliament as an independent, causing turmoil for the government. Katter's use of the term 'black puppet' has drawn criticism on social media, with some questioning the terminology. Katter defended his statement, attributing his choice of words to his own experiences and the belief that the government's attitude had racial overtones. He also compared Gordon's situation to that of federal independents Tony Windsor and Rob Oakeshott, who he believes became puppets of the government, but assured that Gordon would maintain his independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, who was born with cerebral palsy, is using dance to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment due to her disability, Dayna creates enthusiastic dance videos to show that she, like everyone else, can lead a full life. Her goal is to change perceptions in the television, film, and fashion industries and to encourage people to look beyond disabilities. Dayna has produced multiple videos, including one set to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," and she emphasizes that while she may do things differently, she should not be treated differently. She aims to turn negativity into positivity and has started motivational speaking at local schools, sharing her message that she is more than her disability.

Orlando City, an MLS team, has shown interest in Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has had a difficult loan spell at Real Madrid. Hernandez, a Mexico international, could be a significant commercial asset for the Florida-based club due to its large Latin-American fanbase. Orlando City, coached by Adrian Heath, has already made inquiries about a potential deal. Despite Hernandez's struggles at Real Madrid, he is popular among Orlando supporters and is also attracting interest from eight European clubs. Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan are among those interested, with Manchester United willing to sell for approximately £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has made a revised contract offer to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira, who has attracted interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting United's initial offer.

On Saturday morning, at least three individuals attacked a car at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles by pouring gasoline on it and setting it on fire. The incident occurred around 12:15 am after an argument between the driver and the suspects during a gas fill-up. Two passengers were inside the white Dodge Charger when it was engulfed in flames, but no one was injured. The car, however, was completely destroyed. The driver's grandmother reported that the suspects had attempted to carjack her grandson, who fled upon seeing a gun. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the case as arson, and the suspects are still at large. Surveillance footage is being used in the investigation.

Charles Manuel, a chiropractor from Lamoni, Iowa, has surrendered his state license following accusations of accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. Manuel signed an agreement admitting to these actions and vowed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years. The agreement stipulates that he must prove the circumstances leading to the revocation no longer exist before he can practice again. These circumstances included bartering sex for services and advising patients to stop taking prescribed medication. Despite these serious allegations, Manuel has received high patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, with three positive reviews giving him a perfect five-star rating. His former practice's address listed on Yelp corresponds to a residential location in Lamoni.

The United States is lodging a complaint with Russia over an incident where a Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in what the Pentagon describes as an "unsafe and unprofessional manner." The U.S. aircraft was in international airspace north of Poland when the Russian jet approached at a high rate of speed and performed aggressive maneuvers. The Russian Defense Ministry claims the U.S. plane was heading toward the Russian border with its transponder off, which the U.S. denies. This encounter is not the first of its kind; a similar incident occurred a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk, where a Russian jet came within 100 feet of a U.S. RC-135U. The Pentagon and State Department plan to address this latest incident through diplomatic channels with Russia.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in the parking lot of a Salt Lake City hotel, the Marriott Springhill Suites, days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The gun, inside a hard case, was secured to a truck safe with padlocks and chains. The thief broke the car window, used a rope to break the case's handle free, and pulled the frame from the door. The agent's gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools were also stolen. The bags and some clothing were later found at a nearby hotel, but the rifle remains missing. The theft occurred overnight on March 27. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras. The rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was informed of the theft before Obama's visit, but any impact on security is unknown. It's unclear if the car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, 71, is on trial for the murder of his neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in 2012. The incident occurred in the dining room of Costa's home in Red Hill, Canberra, where he allegedly stomped on Freebody's head, cut his throat, and stabbed him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen testified that Costa showed signs of declining mental health, likely due to dementia and alcohol abuse, which compromised his brain function and understanding of his actions during the event. Mullen's assessment is based on Costa's fluctuating mood during the incident, as evidenced by his triple 0 calls, and his confused state indicated by a trail of faeces from the crime scene to the toilet. The prosecutor, Shane Drumgold, suggested Costa may have pretended to have memory issues during interviews, but Mullen disagreed. Costa's mental state at the time of the murder is crucial to the case, as it could lead to a not guilty verdict if his instability is proven.

In a match against Burnley at Goodison Park, Everton's Ross Barkley took a penalty instead of the more experienced Leighton Baines, who has a strong record of scoring penalties in the Premier League. Barkley's attempt was saved by Burnley's goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Everton manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision, stating that multiple players are capable of taking penalties and it depends on how they feel in the moment. Despite the missed penalty, Everton won the match 1-0 with a goal from Kevin Mirallas.

Two passengers on a Holland America Line cruise ship, the ms Ryndam, were found dead in what appears to be a murder-suicide in their stateroom while the ship was in Puerto Rico. The incident was discovered on Thursday, and the cabin was immediately secured with authorities, including the FBI, notified. The ship had departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise and was in San Juan at the time of the incident. The cleaning staff reportedly discovered the bodies after knocking on the cabin's door.

Patrick Kluivert, the former Holland forward and assistant coach, has led Curacao to a successful start in World Cup qualifying for the 2018 tournament. Curacao advanced to the second qualifying round in CONCACAF after drawing 2-2 with Montserrat, winning 4-3 on aggregate. Kluivert's team had previously won 2-1 in the first leg. A late goal from Charlton Vicento, a former Holland Under 21 international, secured their progression in the 87th minute. Curacao will face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, who has familial ties to Curacao, previously reached the World Cup semi-finals as both a player in 1998 and as an assistant to Louis van Gaal in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, despite his numerous accolades from major European competitions, considers keeping Leicester City in the Premier League as comparable to winning a trophy. Currently at the bottom of the table with seven points behind, Leicester faces a tough battle with only eight games left. Cambiasso, who has won 15 trophies during his time at Inter Milan, including the Champions League, Serie A, Coppa Italia, and FIFA Club World Cup, remains optimistic. He believes that the team, despite not having won a game since January, still has a chance to avoid relegation. Cambiasso, who joined Leicester after a decade in Italy, is content with his move and his family's well-being in the East Midlands, hinting at a possible extension beyond his current one-year deal.

The passage details the situation of a 23-year-old woman, referred to as Gemma, who is at risk of being barred from seeing her two children, both under five years old, by her own mother, Debbie. Gemma had two children with two different fathers and passed the care of both infants to Debbie when they were four months old. Debbie, who is 52, is considering banning Gemma from visiting the children due to her daughter's substance use, including a legal high called MKat, and suspicions of theft. Debbie took over childcare after social services threatened to intervene, and she is concerned about Gemma's drinking, partying, and alleged theft of an iPad from one of the children to fund her lifestyle. Gemma admits to past thefts from her mother but denies stealing the iPad. Debbie, who has raised the children alone, is considering banning Gemma from her home and from seeing the children, as she cannot trust her not to steal from them. The children refer to Debbie as 'mum' rather than 'grandma'. Debbie expresses her love for the grandchildren and her disappointment in Gemma's priorities, urging her to mature and stop her substance use and partying.

During a match at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored the opening goal against Manchester United, but the validity of the goal was questioned by the Sky Sports punditry team due to a preceding incident. Chelsea's John Terry made a strong challenge from behind on United's Radamel Falcao, causing him to fall and leading to a loose ball that Cesc Fabregas capitalized on, eventually assisting Hazard's goal. Pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness argued during half-time analysis that Terry's tackle on Falcao was a foul and play should have been stopped. Souness specifically criticized the tackle, describing it as a 'decent forearm smash,' while Henry and Redknapp also agreed that the challenge was foul play, with Redknapp noting that although Falcao could have been stronger, Terry's action was still a foul.

Lady Antebellum's tour bus caught fire on Interstate 30 near Dallas, Texas, but all occupants, including singer Hillary Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver, were safely evacuated. The fire occurred after a rear tire blew out, and it was captured on video by Michael Barnett, who uploaded it to CNN iReport. Scott posted photos of the aftermath on Instagram, expressing gratitude for the safety of all involved and noting that her Bible was the only item not destroyed in the bus's back lounge. The band is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards. Band members Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood were not on the bus at the time of the incident.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman of Dundee University is exploring the use of space lasers to convert sunlight into energy, which could potentially power homes on Earth. The concept involves satellites orbiting the Earth, equipped with mirrors to capture sunlight and convert it into laser light. This energy, generated using semi-conductors, can then be transmitted back to Earth. While initial trials in Scotland have been successful, Dr. Quarterman plans to conduct further tests in Portugal. The lasers are not powerful enough to be used as weapons, unlike their fictional counterparts in movies. However, the scientist acknowledges concerns about the control of such technology. This project is distinct from a proposal by Tokyo researchers to use lasers on the International Space Station to clear space debris, which also would not be weaponizable.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted pedophile with a fixation on young girls, has absconded from a psychiatric unit. Munden, who was detained under the Mental Health Act for sexually touching a three-year-old girl, was last seen leaving a hospital near Hook, Hampshire. A manhunt has been initiated to locate him. Munden is described as 5ft 8ins tall, heavy-built, with dark hair, and may have shaved off his beard. He was convicted of sexually touching a child under 13 and had admitted to possessing indecent images of children. Munden has learning difficulties and an "obsession with young girls," according to court proceedings. Authorities are urging anyone with information on his whereabouts to come forward urgently.

A Los Angeles judge has ordered V. Stiviano to repay over $2.6 million in gifts she received from Donald Sterling, following a lawsuit by Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. Shelly accused Stiviano of targeting wealthy older men and claimed that the gifts, including a Ferrari, two Bentleys, a Range Rover, and a $1.8 million duplex, were bought with the couple's money. Stiviano argued that there was nothing wrong with the gifts and that she did not take advantage of Donald Sterling. The court decision was celebrated by Shelly Sterling's lawyer, who called it a victory for the Sterling family and a precedent for injured spouses to recover damages from recipients of such gifts. The gifts also included less expensive items like a costume, a blender, and lingerie. Donald Sterling was banned from the NBA, fined $2.5 million, and stripped of his ownership rights in the Los Angeles Clippers after an audio recording surfaced of him making racist remarks to Stiviano.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player and now a Sky Sports pundit, has criticized Arsenal's recent transfer strategies and urged the club to acquire four high-quality players in the summer to contend for the Premier League title. Henry believes Arsenal require a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a top striker. He used Chelsea's successful signings of Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa as an example of the impact quality signings can have. Henry also expressed doubt over Arsenal's ability to win the league with Olivier Giroud as their first-choice striker, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season.

The passage details the court testimony of a young woman who was abused by Maurice Van Ryn, the boss of Bega Cheese. Van Ryn, a wealthy businessman from NSW, has admitted to 12 sex offenses, one of which is the persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim expressed her fear for future relationships and the impact of the abuse on her life, stating that Van Ryn had taken away her right to share her body with someone for the first time. She mentioned that she was unaware of the wrongfulness of the acts when she was a child and only came forward when she learned of Van Ryn's apprehension. Since then, she has struggled with depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide. The woman also expressed concern about Van Ryn's eventual release and its potential effect on her interactions with men. The court hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, the 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is nearing a return to full fitness after being sidelined for over a year due to a serious knee injury. His last appearance for the first team was in March 2014 during the Champions League match against Bayern Munich. Gnabry, who had made a strong impression the previous season, played a full 90 minutes for Arsenal's Under-21 team against Reading, indicating his recovery is on track. He expressed his positive state, saying he feels "better and better" and is looking forward to the next game, free from injury concerns.
