Elliott expressed satisfaction with the outcome, noting it could have been resolved 19 months prior.

Hawick Knitwear, a company with over 230 employees and a history dating back to 1874, has increased its sweater production to 9,500 units per week to meet high demand. This surge in production follows the successful launch of its own branded range in January and continued growth in its private label business. The company, now owned by managing director Benny Hartop, serves a wide market, including Europe (Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain) and non-European countries such as the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. The increase in production is a direct response to a rise in orders both domestically and internationally. Hartop attributes the company's positive outlook to the dedication of its staff.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, sustained serious head injuries when she was hit by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light, which his VW Golf failed to stop for. He has expressed deep regret for the incident, acknowledging the beloved status of Mrs. Blackburn among the community and the children. Despite his remorse, Wright denies the charge of causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn, who had been assisting a woman and her daughter to cross the road when the incident occurred, is now receiving treatment in residential care. The trial is ongoing.

The passage describes a NATO exercise, codenamed "Dynamic Mongoose," aimed at training for anti-submarine warfare, highlighting the growing concern over Russia's increasing military strength and submarine activity. The exercise involves 10 NATO warships, including the USS Vicksburg and HMS Portland, and is focused on locating the German U-boat U33, which is simulating an enemy submarine. The task is likened to finding a needle in a haystack due to the vastness of the ocean and the stealth capabilities of submarines. The exercise also includes anti-submarine warfare helicopters and, for the first time, underwater unmanned vehicles to aid in detection. The lack of long-range maritime patrol aircraft in the UK's arsenal is noted as a significant gap in defenses, with the exercise serving as a reminder of the need for such capabilities. The passage underscores the technological advancements and operational skills of Russian submarines, which are described as the "quietest and most challenging adversary in the world," capable of going undetected for months. The exercise is part of NATO's response to the perceived threat from Russian submarines, which have been reported off the coasts of Sweden, Finland, and the UK.

The passage discusses the escalating violence in South Sudan, which has led to a mass exodus of refugees into neighboring Uganda. Since the violence began in July, over 340,000 people have fled, making it the largest refugee crisis of the year, surpassing even Syria. The conflict, rooted in ethnic tensions between the Dinka and Nuer tribes, has now expanded to include targeting of Equatorians. Refugees report widespread atrocities, including killings, rape, and theft. Uganda, while coping well with the influx, is beginning to struggle with the strain on resources. The UNHCR calls for international attention and pressure on South Sudanese leaders to halt the violence, which is described as a massacre of civilians. The situation is dire, with half of the refugees being children and reports of trauma and loss among the displaced population.

The passage highlights that 38-year-old boxer McKenzie, who transitioned from football to boxing in 2013, is set to face Jahmaine Smyle on 12 November for the English super-middleweight championship at York Hall. With a record of eight wins and one draw from nine fights, McKenzie, the son of ex-champion Clinton and trained by his uncle Duke, a former three-time world champion, is advancing in his boxing career.

The passage discusses the planned development of a new community hospital in Bridgwater, funded partly by the coalition's £330m investment for new NHS facilities in England. The new hospital, costing £33m in total, will feature 30 inpatient beds, a maternity unit, a minor injury unit, and X-ray facilities. The current hospital, built in 1813, is described as outdated and in poor condition by Matron Sue Taylor. The remaining funds for the project will be provided by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new facility is expected to improve patient well-being and care delivery, as noted by Dr Donal Hynes, a local GP. The hospital is intended to be constructed on Bowers Lane, with the goal of completion by autumn 2014, pending planning permission.

A man was fatally shot in the chest outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace, Upperthorpe, near the city center. He was found near a black Mercedes he had been driving. Police arrived at 13:35 GMT, and the victim was taken to Northern General hospital where he later died. The man was part of a family living nearby, and the shooting happened during a family gathering. Several recent shootings have occurred in Sheffield, but this is the first in the Upperthorpe area. Previous incidents include a 25-year-old man shot in Shiregreen, an elderly couple's home targeted in Southey Green, and two separate shootings in High Green in January.

The passage discusses the activities of various hacker groups involved in the conflict between Ukraine and Russia. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, have hacked Russian servers and email accounts, sharing data with Ukrainian security services and volunteer groups like Inform Napalm. They use DDoS attacks to disrupt rebel websites and target funding accounts. The group also monitors CCTV systems for military movements and has hijacked network printers to print pro-Ukrainian messages. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, aims to thwart Ukrainian military plans and has hacked Ukrainian government websites during Joe Biden's visit, claiming to retrieve confidential documents. They have also hacked billboards and disrupted electronic vote-counting systems. Anonymous International, also known as b0ltai, publishes leaked documents from the Kremlin, focusing on Russia's domestic affairs but also covering Ukraine, including emails from a Russian fighter suggesting a lack of local support for separatists.

The passage details the emotional farewells of veteran Scottish politicians at the Scottish Parliament ahead of the May 5th election. Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, shed tears during the farewell speeches of Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond. Salmond, reflecting on his time in office, emphasized Scotland's diversity and strength, and critiqued the Scotland Bill for not fully delivering on promises made by unionist politicians. He also injected humor into his speech, referencing the Chancellor's UK budget and the Cheltenham racecourse. McNeil, stepping down after serving since 1999, warned the parliament about the need for accountability, scrutiny, and opposition, suggesting there are lessons to be learned from Westminster. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also bid farewell, humorously recalling her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick praised Salmond's service to the parliament and Scotland.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care for older people in residential care in Wales. She aims to gather experiences from pensioners, their friends, and families to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from those directly affected by residential care, noting both the positive impacts of high-quality care and the unacceptable variations in care quality across Wales. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Mario Kreft, chair of Care Forum Wales, supports the review's aims but expresses disappointment that no provider expert is included on the main advisory panel, suggesting a missed opportunity for partnership and sector engagement.

Harbro Group, a company based in Aberdeenshire, reported a pre-tax profit increase of £800,000, reaching £3.5m by the end of June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. The company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors and operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, saw growth in international sales in Europe and new markets. Harbro acknowledges the unpredictability of the agriculture sector and the challenges of the past 18 months, but remains confident in the industry's robustness. The company is also prepared for the potential impacts of Brexit on its business.

The body of a man in his 70s was discovered at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on a Saturday afternoon. Another man in his 80s was taken to the hospital. Police are searching for 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the murder investigation and have cautioned the public not to approach him. McLoughlin is described as a white male, approximately 6ft tall, with greying, collar-length hair, and of average build. He was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a dark blue, light blue, and white checked short-sleeved shirt. The police are urging anyone with information to come forward and are conducting additional patrols in the area for resident reassurance.

David Lipton, the IMF's second in command, highlighted risks and a weakening global economy in a speech to the National Association for Business Economics. This follows disappointing trade data from China, with exports down by a quarter year-over-year. The IMF expects to revise its global growth forecast of 3.4% downwards in April. This economic downturn has continuous impacts on businesses and sectors that relied on China's growth.

The passage discusses the issues surrounding a new ferry service at Cowes, which has experienced a series of problems since its launch on May 14, including breakdowns, grounding, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, and damage to cars. In response to these issues, the council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the crossing would be free until July 2 to gather feedback and acknowledged the disappointing start. The council has ordered a project review by auditors. Local businesses, affected by the ferry's issues, are uncertain about their survival and are seeking compensation, which is under discussion. Transport councillor Ian Ward defended the ferry as a prototype with expected initial problems, stating that electrical issues have been fixed and ramp extensions were authorized to prevent vehicle damage. Grounding issues were attributed to seamanship and have been resolved.

A fatal crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott, resulting in the death of a 32-year-old man. The incident happened around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by careless driving. The road was shut between Thursley and Liphook for investigation until early evening.

The passage discusses a controversy involving Matching Models in London, an agency that specializes in hiring attractive and talented individuals. The agency posted job advertisements specifying physical attributes for roles, such as a personal assistant with "a classic look, brown long hair with b-c cup" and a "sexy female driver" for a businessman. The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) condemned these practices as "appalling, unlawful, and demeaning to women," and women's equality campaigners likened them to the 1970s. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defended the practices, stating that looks are important to their clients. Employment lawyer James Lynas noted that such advertisements are likely unlawful and could lead to discrimination claims. The EHRC plans to contact Matching Models to clarify their hiring practices. The agency's clients include major brands like MTV, Louis Vuitton, and Harrods. The controversy highlights issues of gender equality and discrimination in the workplace.

A shooting incident occurred at a hostel connected to the Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, involving an office assistant named Mahesh who is alleged to have shot two students. One student, Gautami, was fatally shot in the head, while the other, Sirisha, sustained severe injuries but is expected to survive. Mahesh has been arrested and is in police custody until April 12. The motive for the shooting is unclear. School shootings are uncommon in India, with strict gun control laws in place, although firearms are sometimes used to settle disputes. A previous school shooting in 2007 resulted in the death of a 14-year-old student near Delhi.

The advocacy group Glaad conducted an analysis of TV shows aired between June 2016 and May 2017, identifying 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters. There was an increase in transgender characters from seven to 16. However, Glaad criticized the trend of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters being killed off, including Poussey Washington from "Orange is the New Black" and Bea Smith from "Wentworth." The report also noted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast television, attributed to shows like "Empire," "Luke Cage," and "How to Get Away with Murder." Glaad's study was based on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series that were either airing or had confirmed casting. Glaad's president, Sarah Kate Ellis, acknowledged progress but emphasized that numbers only tell part of the story.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided not to stand for re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was likely to be opposed. This decision follows reports that millions of pounds, loaned to Northampton Town FC for stadium rebuilding and land development, have gone missing. Mackintosh, who was the borough council leader when the loan was made, is under criticism and the matter is subject to a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities. Despite denying any wrongdoing, a majority of his party's local executive council stated they would vote to deselect him. Mackintosh, who has been the MP since 2015, expressed that he feels it is the right time for his constituents to have a new representative.

In April, Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old police officer, fatally shot 15-year-old Jordan Edwards in a car leaving a party in Balch Springs, a suburb of Dallas. Oliver fired into the vehicle, which was carrying teenagers, after police responded to reports of underage drinking at the party. Initially, police claimed the car reversed aggressively towards the officer, but video evidence contradicted this, showing the car moving away. Oliver was subsequently fired for policy violations and has been charged with murder, facing a potential sentence of 5 to 99 years in prison. Additionally, he faces four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon by a public official for the other teenagers in the car, including two of Jordan's brothers. If convicted, Oliver would be the first police officer in Dallas County to be convicted of murder since 1973. The trial date has not been set, and Oliver is currently on bail. The Edwards family's lawyer, Lee Merritt, expressed caution, noting the rarity of police convictions in Texas.

The summary is as follows:

President-elect Donald Trump's wife Melania and their son Barron will not move into the White House until the summer, after Barron has finished school. This decision has attracted criticism on social media, with some questioning its impact on the Trumps' marriage. However, Melania's decision has its supporters, with some noting that it is not uncommon for children to stay behind to finish school when a parent becomes president. Historically, only two other First Ladies have not lived in the White House during their husbands' presidencies: Martha Washington and Anna Harrison. Melania has indicated that Barron will be her top priority, suggesting she may not take on the full-time role of First Lady that predecessors like Michelle Obama have. The role of the First Lady is officially ceremonial, but has evolved in recent times to include active public roles and support for various causes. Melania has expressed interest in tackling cyber-bullying.

The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, is investigating the initial police response to a call from a 72-year-old man who was later found deceased at a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on October 27. Police Scotland is cooperating fully with the investigation, awaiting the findings. The Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) instructed Pirc to conduct the investigation, and a report on the commissioner's findings will be submitted to COPFS.

The passage details a weather warning issued for strong winds affecting several counties in Wales. Key points include:

1. A yellow warning for wind has been issued, with potential gusts of up to 75mph (120kmph) locally, particularly to the west of the mountains.
2. The easterly direction of the wind is noted as unusual and could exacerbate its impact.
3. Disruption to travel on roads and at sea is expected.
4. The warning applies to the counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys.
5. A tree was blown down overnight in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, closing a main route into the town.
6. Telford Road is expected to remain closed for most of Monday for clean-up operations.

In the game between the Giants and the Panthers, the Giants initially scored through player-coach Derrick Walser. The Panthers equalized with a goal from Jeff Dimmen. In the second period, Mike Forney scored a powerplay breakaway goal for the Panthers, followed by an equalizer from Andy Bohmback. Mike Radja and James Desmarais then scored for the Panthers, making it 4-2. David Ling scored for Nottingham, reducing the lead. The teams will play again on Saturday night. Nottingham is currently leading the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

In the Chinese Grand Prix, Lewis Hamilton, starting from the back due to a broken front wing on the first lap and making five pit stops, finished outside the podium, increasing the championship lead of Nico Rosberg to 36 points. Sebastian Vettel came in second despite a collision with teammate Kimi Raikkonen at the start, which damaged both cars. Raikkonen recovered to fifth place, passing Hamilton late in the race, aided by Ferrari's choice of soft tires over Mercedes' mediums. The race was marked by several first-lap incidents, including Hamilton being turned into by Felipe Nasr while avoiding Raikkonen's damaged car. Vettel confronted Daniil Kvyat about his aggressive driving, but Kvyat defended his actions, saying he saw a gap and took it. Daniel Ricciardo, who had a strong start, suffered a puncture and could not challenge Rosberg, who led serenely after the safety car period. Hamilton's car was damaged in the incident with Nasr, affecting his performance and complicating his championship defense.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a retired professional footballer, has publicly come out as gay in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to advance the discussion on homosexuality in German football, which has been largely ignored. His announcement has been met with widespread support from former teammates, prominent figures in German football administration, and the public. Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich praised his courage, while Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball commended his decision as a significant step against homophobia. Bayern Munich also expressed support. Hitzlsperger's revelation is considered a watershed moment in Germany, where homophobia in football has been a persistent issue. This contrasts with comments made by Philipp Lahm in 2011, who advised gay footballers to remain silent about their sexuality. The last German footballer to come out was Marcus Urban in 2007. Angela Merkel's spokesman and openly gay politician Volker Beck also praised Hitzlsperger, hoping his action will encourage others and lead to greater openness in football. Zwanziger expressed optimism that sexuality will soon be a non-issue in the sport.

The passage discusses the situation of 34-year-old midfielder Steve Sidwell, who has contributed to Brighton & Hove Albion's (the Seagulls) promotion to the Premier League after 34 years. With his contract ending, Sidwell expresses his desire to renew his deal, believing the team can maintain their Premier League status. Brighton's victory over Wigan secured their promotion, and they aim to clinch the league title in the last two matches, leading by four points over Newcastle. Sidwell joined Brighton on loan from Stoke in 2015-16, making 19 appearances, and signed a one-year contract in June 2016. Having played in the Premier League with Reading, Chelsea, Aston Villa, Fulham, and Stoke, Sidwell feels he has earned the chance to play at the top level again. He notes that his performance exceeded expectations and hopes to finalize a new contract to enjoy the upcoming season.

Blackpool and Colchester United drew 1-1 in their match. Blackpool took the lead when Nathan Delfouneso's chip was turned in by Jamille Matt. Colchester equalized from a corner when Kurtis Guthrie scored in a goalmouth scramble. Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a chance to win the game when he headed wide from a corner. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle. The match ended with both teams having several attempts but unable to score again.

The passage discusses a 29-year-old football player who appeared 37 times for the Sky Blues (Coventry City) in the previous season, which ended with their relegation from League One. The player, identified later as Reid, has previously played for Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. Reid is anticipated to potentially debut for Colchester United, referred to as the U's, in their EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa, a Championship side, on Wednesday. The text also mentions that Colchester United began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington on the previous Saturday. Lastly, it directs readers to a dedicated page for the latest football transfers.

The passage discusses the increased push for the creation of a permanent memorial for police officers and staff who have died in the line of duty, following the murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament. The UK Police Memorial Trust is leading the initiative and has appealed for £1.5m towards the construction at the National Memorial Arboretum. The memorial will bear the names of over 1,400 officers and staff and is intended to be a place for the nation to honor and commemorate the police service. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out, which will be given to the families of fallen officers as a personal memorial. The government has committed £1m towards the £4m needed for the memorial, which is expected to be completed by 2019. The memorial will be dedicated to the courage and sacrifice of officers who have lost their lives over the past 250 years.

The passage discusses Manchester United's position in the Premier League, 15 points ahead at the top with eight games remaining, following a 1-0 win against Sunderland. Manager Alex Ferguson emphasizes focusing on upcoming games, highlighting the team's record of 25 wins out of the first 30 matches. The next significant game is the derby against Manchester City, with United having a 15-point lead. The team aims to better Chelsea's record 95-point haul from 2005. Ferguson plans to make changes for the FA Cup quarter-final replay against Chelsea due to injuries sustained by Rafael, Anderson, and David De Gea. He mentions the potential availability of Ryan Giggs, Javier Hernandez, and others for the Chelsea match. The win against Sunderland was characterized by determined defending and courage, despite a challenging second half.

In a BBC interview, Google's Eric Schmidt defended the company's tax practices, stating that Google pays the legally required amount of taxes in the UK, which amounted to £10m between 2006 and 2011. He emphasized that tax payment is not optional and that Google complies with the laws in place. Schmidt suggested that any changes to tax systems should be made by governments, and Google would adjust its payments accordingly. Meanwhile, Margaret Hodge, head of the UK's Public Accounts Committee, proposed a new committee to oversee major firms' tax arrangements, suggesting that companies should not be able to hide behind confidentiality rules. Google, which routes most of its UK sales through Ireland, has been criticized for minimizing its UK tax payments. EU leaders recently agreed to address tax avoidance through better information exchange among tax authorities. Schmidt has advocated for corporate taxes to be based on where economic activity and risks are taken, not where products are consumed, and has called for a debate on international tax reform. He believes politicians should set tax rules and that companies should be commended for abiding by the law.

The NHS is attempting to reduce its spending on agency staff, which amounted to £3.6bn last year, by £1bn by the end of the financial year. A cap introduced in October has saved £600m so far. The cap limits payments to 55% above normal shift rates for all staff except senior managers. The aim is to reduce costs and dependence on agency staff, who are more expensive due to agency fees and employer costs. Progress has been made, but NHS trusts are 10% behind their target. The impact on other parts of the pay bill is unclear. NHS Improvement will publish league tables of trusts' agency spending and information on the highest-earning agency staff. Some hospitals have been quoted rates double the cap. The NHS needs to further reduce expensive agency staff spending, according to NHS Improvement CEO Jim Mackey.

The passage discusses the economic situation in Longford, Ireland, post the Celtic Tiger crash. The Longford Town Centre, once envisioned as a commercial hub, now symbolizes the economic downturn. Local trader Matt O'Brien, who runs a men's clothing shop, experienced a 30% decline in business during the bad times but has noticed an improvement in the last year. The shop has diversified into children's wear and dress hire to boost sales. Fianna Fáil criticizes the government's investment priorities, advocating for broadband improvements over water meters. The government, however, points to the Center Parcs tourism development, expected to create 1,000 jobs by 2019, as a positive initiative. Local Fine Gael TD James Bannon highlights the area's scenic attractions and welcomes tourism. Traders like O'Brien suggest that free parking could further aid local businesses. Overall, while signs of economic recovery are evident, more support is needed for local commerce.

The passage details a cricket tournament concluding on 29 May. Eight teams are participating, playing each other twice, with the top four advancing to the playoffs. Key statistics include leading run-scorers Warner (294), Kohli (267), and De Villiers (249), and most sixes by Warner (12) and De Villiers (12). De Kock has the highest score in an innings (108), and McClenaghan leads in wickets (9). Four England players are involved: Morgan, Buttler, Billings, and Pietersen. The schedule lists daily fixtures from 25 April to 29 May, including qualifier matches and the final on 29 May.

The Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs reported a 200 million increase in plastic carrier bags since 2013, leading to environmental issues due to their non-recyclability and disposal. In response, England will implement a 5p charge per bag from October, following the successful reduction in usage observed in Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland after introducing similar charges. The aim is to encourage bag reuse and reduce environmental harm.

Here is a summary of the passage:

- A school roof was damaged in Rhosgadfan near Caernarfon, Gwynedd, and numerous homes across Wales experienced power outages.
- Train delays, speed and lane restrictions on major bridges, and power cuts affected many homes following a yellow 'be aware' warning for wind across Wales.
- Friday was one of the busiest days on UK roads due to the Christmas getaway and the end of the working week.
- The highest wind gusts were recorded at Mona on Anglesey.
- Irish Ferries canceled six fast sailings between Holyhead and Dublin due to adverse weather conditions, transferring passengers to cruise ferry services.
- Arriva Trains Wales warned of speed restrictions and possible delays for all services between Llandudno Junction to Holyhead.
- The National Trust closed Erddig Hall and Chirk Castle in Wrexham due to expected high winds.
- Restrictions on the A55 Britannia Bridge and the M48 Severn Bridge were lifted as winds eased into Friday evening.
- Rhyl's Boxing Day Dip in Denbighshire was postponed to Tuesday, 27 December, due to a blustery forecast for the Christmas weekend.

The passage highlights that an unnamed individual, presumably Michael B. Jordan, expressed excitement about his involvement in the upcoming Black Panther film, aiming to bring a fresh perspective to his role. He looks forward to reuniting with director Ryan Coogler, with whom he previously worked on Creed. Jordan also expresses enthusiasm about working with Lupita Nyong'o and Chadwick Boseman. The film is set for release in February 2018. Notably, Jordan had previously played the Human Torch in the unsuccessful Fantastic Four reboot, while Nyong'o had a role as Maz Kanata in Star Wars: The Force Awakens.

The passage discusses the restoration of an 1875-founded theatre and BBC studios at the eastern end of a palace, aiming for a 2018 reopening pending successful fundraising. This project is part of a larger east wing restoration to turn Alexandra Palace into a cultural destination. Renovations include creating public and exhibition spaces in the glazed east court. The Heritage Lottery Fund is providing £18.8m, Haringey Council £6.8m, for a total refurbishment cost of £26.6m. The Alexandra Park and Palace Charitable Trust aims to raise the final £1m by summer 2017. The theatre, unused for decades, retains original decor and stage machinery, originally used for opera, musicals, plays, and early cinema.

The passage is about the retirement of a 30-year-old former Manchester City player from the England national team. He earned 61 caps since his debut in 2009, participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, but had limited playtime at Euro 2016. He expressed his decision as 'common sense' and wished the team well for the future. The player also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps. He scored his only international goal during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers in a match against Moldova.

The house of Marcy Smith in Glovertown, Newfoundland and Labrador, was destroyed by fire, with the family's dog and cats perishing in the blaze. Smith and her daughter were awakened by her son David, who noticed the flames while on a FaceTime call with his father. The fire, which started from rubbish burned in the wood stove, spread rapidly, engulfing the kitchen while they were in it. Despite the fire alarm not going off, the family managed to escape wearing only their pyjamas. The community has supported them by donating clothes, shoes, and a bike for David. Smith is immensely proud of her son for saving their lives and plans to remind him of his heroic act.

The passage discusses the ownership and potential sale of the Premier League club, West Ham. Key points include:

1. Rumors circulated that an energy drinks company was contemplating a £200m bid for the club.
2. David Sullivan and David Gold acquired a controlling interest in West Ham in 2010, with the club then valued at £105m.
3. Sullivan and Gold currently hold over 85% of the club's shares.
4. West Ham has been associated with takeover interests from Qatari and Chinese investors since relocating to London Stadium in August.
5. Sullivan previously mentioned the possibility of selling a minority stake to alleviate debt but affirmed that he and Gold plan to pass ownership to their offspring.

The MTV Movie Awards, described as less formal than the Oscars by 22 Jump Street's Jillian Bell, celebrated with fan-voted categories such as best kiss and best shirtless performance, which Zac Efron won. The event also served as a promotional stage for upcoming summer blockbusters. The Fault in Our Stars was the night's big winner, claiming the best movie award, with Shailene Woodley receiving best female performance, the Trailblazer Award, and best kiss with Ansel Elgort. Woodley dedicated her speech to John Green, the author of the book the film is based on. Bradley Cooper won best male performance for American Sniper, honoring the late Chris Kyle. Channing Tatum and Meryl Streep won best comedic performance and best villain, respectively. Other winners included Jennifer Lopez, Jennifer Lawrence, Seth Rogen, and Rose Byrne. Kevin Hart, receiving the comedic genius award, brought his kids on stage, stating he works for them. Robert Downey Jr. accepted the Generation Award with his Avengers co-stars in a lively moment. The ceremony also featured clips from upcoming films like Pitch Perfect sequel, Trainwreck, and Marvel's Ultron.

The passage discusses the loan of Cammy Smith, a 21-year-old player, from Aberdeen (The Dons) to St Mirren (United). Smith, who has scored five goals this season and has a total of four goals in 89 appearances for Aberdeen since his debut in 2012, is described as a "brilliant acquisition" by St Mirren's boss, Jack Ross. Ross highlights Smith's maturity and believes he will be a good fit for the team, providing an additional attacking option. St Mirren, currently at the bottom of the Championship, is set to play against Falkirk on Saturday.

The Northumberland County Council has initiated a pothole repair program using Jetpatcher machines, now that the weather is suitable for such activities. They aim to fix 145 potholes daily for the next four months. Additionally, the council will employ more staff to repair rain-damaged drainage systems and clear gutters of debris.

In December 2016, six Wood Group contractors, including rigging supervisor Steve Innes, were exposed to alpha radiation while working on EnQuest's Thistle platform, 125 miles northeast of Shetland. The workers were doing shutdown work with pipe equipment when they were informed of the radiation exposure. EnQuest stated that the level of exposure was less than 1% of the reportable level to the Health and Safety Executive (HSE) but informed the HSE nonetheless. Additional precautionary steps have since been taken by EnQuest to prevent future exposure to naturally occurring radioactive material (NORM). Wood Group emphasized its commitment to employee safety and conducted medical assessments of the affected workers. John Boland of the Unite union criticized the treatment of the workers and stressed the importance of transparency in safety incidents. The HSE was aware of the incident but noted it was not reportable under current regulations and no separate investigation was requested by the staff.

The Asian Civilisation Museum (ACM) in Singapore has decided to return a bronze sculpture of the Hindu goddess Uma Parameshvari to India, following discussions with the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI). The artwork, purchased for $650,000 in 2007 from New York dealer Art of the Past, is believed to have been stolen from a Shiva temple in Tamil Nadu. The dealer's manager, Aaron Freedman, confessed to dealing in looted Indian antiquities and possessing 150 stolen objects. Although there is no definitive proof that the sculpture was stolen, the ACM's decision was influenced by Freedman's confession. The museum plans to seek legal action for compensation due to the apparent fraud. This sculpture was one of 30 items acquired from the dealer, but the only one suspected to be stolen. The ASI was permitted to review the other items.

A magnitude-4.8 earthquake hit 35km north of Lucca, Italy, at a depth of 15.5km, with aftershocks felt across a wide area. The quake, centered in Garfagnana, caused phone lines and power supplies to go down in the area, leading to school evacuations and checks for damage. It was felt as far as Milan, Florence, Bologna, and Modena. No immediate injuries or significant damage were reported. Italy, prone to earthquakes, is still recovering from a 2009 quake in L'Aquila that killed nearly 300 people. In 2012, six scientists and an ex-official were convicted of manslaughter for providing misleading reassurances before the L'Aquila earthquake. The recent tremor was described as "medium-strong" and "fairly shallow" by the INGV.

On September 8, 2016, Austin Grant, a 62-year-old grandfather from Sheffield, expressed his delight at finally seeing results from his plant, despite initial doubts about South Yorkshire's climate being suitable for ripening the fruit, which is still attached to the plant and not yet ready to eat.

Rockstar has delayed the release of the latest version of its open-world adventure game until 24 March, originally scheduled for 27 January. The delay is to allow for additional testing and polish. The company assured fans that the extra time will ensure the game's quality. Online heists will be available on consoles before the PC release. The PC version will offer enhanced detail, with 1080p at 60fps, up to 4K resolution, and support for triple monitor configurations. Minimum PC specifications have been released for players to prepare. Grand Theft Auto V, when initially released on 17 September 2013, became the fastest-selling entertainment product, generating $1bn in revenue in three days.

The 76-year-old artist won the £25,000 John Moores Painting Prize for his work "Squint (19)" at Liverpool's Walker Art Gallery. This marks his first win after being shortlisted in 1991 and making the longlist on three other occasions. The painting, described as "quite extraordinary" by judge Ansel Krut, depicts a leper squint from medieval churches. Simpson plans to use the prize money for art materials, particularly high-quality paints. The John Moores Painting Prize, established in 1957, is one of Britain's oldest art awards, with previous winners including David Hockney and Peter Doig.

The offices of Yeni Safak and Yeni Akit, both supporting Turkey's governing AK Party, were attacked by four masked assailants, with no reported casualties. The attacks occurred simultaneously at night, involving gunfire that shattered windows in both buildings, located 20km apart. Firefighters quickly put out a resulting blaze at the Yeni Safak building, and police have cordoned off the area. Numerous spent bullet casings were found at both scenes, and the assailants are being hunted by the police. No group has claimed responsibility for the attacks. This incident follows a previous attack on the daily Hurriyet's offices by pro-government protesters last September.

The 24-year-old ex-Burton player, who was contracted to the Stags, has agreed to join Marcus Bignot's side on a free transfer starting on 1 January. He previously spent the season's first half on loan at Crawley, scoring three times in 23 games, and marks Bignot's first signing for the Mariners.

The passage discusses Arsène Wenger's comments on the possibility of Gareth Southgate becoming the permanent manager of the England national football team. Wenger, whose contract with Arsenal runs until the summer, has been linked with the England job but states he is focused on his current role. He praises Southgate, who took over from Sam Allardyce in September, for his experiences and observational skills regarding the national team. Southgate has upcoming matches against Scotland and Spain to prove his worth to the Football Association. Wenger emphasizes that competency is more important than a big name in such roles and believes Southgate has a good opportunity to demonstrate his quality. Additionally, Wenger mentions that Arsenal plans to offer a new contract to defender Hector Bellerin, countering rumors of interest from Barcelona and Manchester City. He also updates on the injury status of midfielder Aaron Ramsey, who will miss one or two more games due to a hamstring injury.

A local man working at Fruehauf on Houghton Road had an accident around 13:45 GMT on Thursday, falling from a cherry picker. Lincolnshire Police is conducting a joint investigation with the Health and Safety Executive. The company is fully cooperating with the ongoing investigation.

The Transport Minister, Humza Yousaf, announced that a new charter arrangement will resolve the longstanding dispute over seafarers' pay on two freight boats, Hellier and Hildasay, operated by Seatruck for Serco Northlink. The RMT union had alleged that some crew members were paid less than £4 an hour. Under the new arrangement, contracted services will revert to Serco Northlink, ensuring all crew members receive at least the minimum wage. The change is expected to take effect next month, pending finalization of financial and regulatory details. Serco Northlink had previously offered to cover the pay gap, but Seatruck declined. The Northern Isles contract, worth £243m over six years, includes three ferries and two cargo boats, heavily subsidized by the Scottish government.

Ken Dickie, 64, died on 14 May following an incident at Rockley Park in Poole on 7 May. Jamie Mitchell, 35, admitted to intervening in an argument between Dickie and Mitchell's mother, Samantha Mitchell, 57. The confrontation escalated, leading to a physical fight where Jamie Mitchell got heavily intoxicated. Both Mitchells lied to the police about the incident, claiming Dickie pushed Samantha, but Jamie later confessed to trying to separate them, resulting in Dickie's death. Jamie Mitchell pleaded guilty to common assault, and both he and his mother admitted to attempting to pervert the course of justice. Sentencing is scheduled for 6 February.

Rod Temperton, the British songwriter and musician known for his work with Michael Jackson and his band Heatwave, has died at the age of 66 after a short battle with cancer. Temperton wrote hits such as "Off the Wall" and "Baby Be Mine" for Jackson, and "Boogie Nights" for Heatwave. He was nicknamed "The Invisible Man" due to his low profile. Temperton's songs contributed to Jackson's "Off the Wall" and "Thriller" albums, with the latter becoming the best-selling album of all time in the US. He won a Grammy in 1990 and was nominated for two Oscars in 1986. Temperton's approach to songwriting was to write something he loved first, ensuring it evoked a strong emotional response. His death has been met with tributes from musicians and industry figures, including Nile Rodgers, LaToya Jackson, and Mark Ronson.

A team of researchers, including Dr Neil Loader and Emeritus Prof Alayne Street-Perrott from Swansea University, have discovered over 450 ancient geoglyphs in the Acre state of the western Brazilian Amazon. These large, geometrical earthworks, possibly 2,000 years old, were concealed by bamboo-dominated rainforest until recent deforestation revealed them. The purpose of these sites remains largely unknown; they are not believed to be defensive structures or villages due to the lack of artifacts and their layout. Instead, they may have been used sporadically for ritual gatherings, akin to Stonehenge or Maya pyramids. Analysis of soil samples suggests they were built amidst taller vegetation, unlike visible structures in other parts of the world. Prior assumptions of the Amazon as a pristine, untouched ecosystem are challenged by this discovery, as evidence points to human influence over 6,000 years, with people cultivating economically valuable trees, creating a "prehistoric supermarket" of useful forest products. This ancient agroforestry may have left a lasting impact on the biodiversity of Acre's remaining forests.

Australian tennis player Nick Kyrgios, aged 21 and ranked 12th in the world, defeated world number 29 Sam Querrey 6-4, 6-4 in 53 minutes, advancing to the second round of the tournament. Kyrgios, who won the Japan Open recently, is nearing the top 10 rankings. He mentioned feeling tired and bored during the match against Querrey, attributing his subdued behavior to fatigue. The player cited the impact of his success in Japan and the travel to the Qi Zhong Stadium in Shanghai, which is an hour away from the city center, as factors affecting his performance. Kyrgios also complained about poor sleep and the long journey to the courts. Last year at the Shanghai Masters, he was fined $1,500 for a foul-mouthed outburst, referring to the event as a "circus."

The passage discusses the call by scientists, charities, and organizations, including Tenovus Cancer Care, BMA Cymru, and Cardiff University's HPV research team, for the Welsh government to extend the human papilloma virus (HPV) vaccination to boys. Currently, the vaccine is given to girls aged 12 and 13 to protect against cervical cancer. The groups argue that the vaccine should also be provided to boys to protect them from head and neck cancers, which are on the rise, particularly among younger men. Dr. Mererid Evans, a consultant oncologist, notes a change in demographics over the last decade, with an increase in cases among non-smokers. Jon Antoniazzi from Tenovus Cancer Care urges the Welsh government to take a proactive step in public health by vaccinating boys. The Welsh government is awaiting advice from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation before making a decision. Since 2008, 85% of girls in Wales have been vaccinated through a school program.

Jak Trueman, a 15-year-old boy from West Lothian, Scotland, who had been battling a rare form of blood cancer called gamma delta T-cell lymphoma, passed away. His journey and positive attitude touched many, as documented on his Facebook page, Jak's Journey, which gained over 28,000 followers. Despite his illness, Jak managed to attend his school prom for a short time. Throughout his treatment, he met with football stars from Rangers FC and received support from various sports teams and the cast of the musical Wicked. Jak's family collected awards on his behalf at the prom, including the Bronze Duke of Edinburgh Award and the Kerry MacGregor Memorial Trophy. After learning that his cancer had spread and further treatment was not an option, Jak and his family focused on raising funds for Leukaemia & Lymphoma Research. A special football match was planned to raise more money for charity in his honor.

In a match with few opportunities, Egypt's El Said scored in the 89th minute with an assist from Mohamed Salah, securing a 1-0 win over Uganda. Earlier, Uganda's Joseph Ochaya had a goal disallowed for offside. The victory puts Egypt in contention for the top spot in Group D against Ghana, while Uganda, in their first tournament since 1978, are eliminated. Ghana, who beat Mali 1-0, have already qualified for the quarter-finals. Despite a resilient performance by Uganda's defense and several saves by their goalkeeper Denis Onyango, they were unable to prevent the late goal. Egypt will play Ghana on Wednesday for the group lead, while Uganda faces Mali, who need a win and a favorable result in the Ghana vs. Egypt match to advance.

Lancashire County Council has selected land from the former Glenburn Sports College and Skelmersdale College for the potential development of a new railway station in Skelmersdale. This decision comes after a comparative study by Network Rail and follows the closure of the sports college and the disuse of Skelmersdale College's Westbank campus, owned by Newcastle College. The council, in partnership with Merseytravel and West Lancashire Borough Council, plans to provide two direct trains to Liverpool per hour. County councillor John Fillis highlighted the chosen location's potential for future expansion, good highway access, and connectivity to the town and surrounding area. The authority will now proceed with acquiring the necessary land. Skelmersdale, designated a new town in 1961, is one of the largest towns in the north west of England without its own railway station, having lost its original station to passengers in 1956.
During a search of a warehouse near Ashbourne, a large number of plants were discovered in an elaborate grow house. A man in his late 40s was arrested at the scene by the police.

A 28-year-old woman of Kurdish origin was severely injured in Hamelin, Lower Saxony, after being dragged through several streets by her neck. Her ex-partner, a 38-year-old German citizen also of Kurdish origin from Bad Muender, later surrendered to authorities. The woman underwent emergency surgery and was transferred to a specialized clinic. The motive behind the attack remains unknown, and police are appealing for witnesses.

A study by Cass Business School and the universities of Warwick and Wisconsin, based on data from the 2013-14 Australian workplace relations survey, found that women are equally as likely as men to ask for a pay rise but are 25% less likely to receive one when compared to like-for-like male and female full-time workers. The research debunks the "reticent female" theory, showing no evidence that women are more hesitant to ask for raises due to fear of upsetting their boss or deviating from gender stereotypes. Factors like employer size, industry, parenthood, and qualifications were accounted for in the analysis. The study suggests some level of discrimination against women in pay negotiations and notes that negotiating behavior may be changing for younger women.

Oxford City Council has been unsuccessful in finding a suitable new burial site despite conducting ground investigations, primarily due to issues with site size, ground conditions, high water table, or restrictive covenants. The two existing cemeteries in Wolvercote and Botley are projected to reach capacity by 2018 and 2021, respectively. The council continues to search for options but faces challenges similar to those in finding new housing sites, having run out of suitable land within Oxford. Once the cemeteries are full, only family plot reopenings, use of reserved plots, and interment of ashes will be possible. The last expansion of burial space in the city occurred in 1932.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, scheduled from 19 to 22 July, will feature an app that provides an augmented reality experience. This app will allow users to access online information, videos, and band interviews by interacting with signs and posters at the festival site on their phones and tablets. The festival will host performances by artists such as The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. HebCelt director Caroline Maclennan highlights that this technology not only enhances the on-site experience but also enables global interaction, allowing people worldwide to engage with the festival and its atmosphere. The app will be updated regularly, offering instant access to information, interviews, and ticket purchases.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, having narrowly beaten Thistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary hemorrhage, a rare occurrence that can affect horses with no known underlying health issues. The horse had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia, characterized by overheating and instability, but had never collapsed before and showed no such symptoms on the day of his death. Many Clouds, owned by Trevor Hemmings and ridden by Leighton Aspell, had a notable career including wins in the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. Trainer Oliver Sherwood described him as the "horse of a lifetime." Despite previous health incidents, the authorities closely monitored his welfare, and his death was not directly linked to his history of overheating.

The passage details a court case where Davina, a 34-year-old transgender woman formerly known as David Ayrton, was convicted of raping a 15-year-old girl in 2004. Davina, who has learning difficulties, denied the charges but was remanded into custody by Judge Ian Pearson, who stated she would likely be held in a male prison due to her pre-transition status. The judge decided against bail, citing risks to Davina's safety and potential non-attendance. The court heard that the victim had clearly remembered the events and had attempted to stop the attack. Davina had disclosed the crime to a care home worker in 2014. Protocols for her detention were discussed, and the case was noted for its unusual nature.

In summary, the Serbian tennis duo lost a match against Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares with a score of 6-4, 6-4 in Rio. This defeat followed a surprise loss by world number one, Novak Djokovic, in the singles event to Juan Martin del Potro of Argentina. Djokovic, aged 29, had previously experienced an unexpected third-round loss at Wimbledon to Sam Querrey. Despite this, he managed to win his 30th Masters title in Toronto prior to the Olympics.

The passage describes an upcoming event in Carrbridge, Cairngorms, where over 20 competitors from various countries including Scotland, England, Ireland, continental Europe, Canada, and the US will participate in a chainsaw carving competition. The carvers are restricted to using only chainsaws to create sculptures of animals and people. The defending champion, Pete Bowsher from Moffat, will be returning to compete for the Claymore Trophy, the prize for the first place winner.

The passage discusses the recovery progress of a 27-year-old rugby player, Webb, who is nearing a return to play after a serious foot injury sustained in a World Cup warm-up with Italy in September. He aims to be fit for the Six Nations tournament in February, with his recovery potentially ahead of schedule. Webb is currently undergoing a pre-season style training phase and plans to assess his condition weekly. His target return date is the beginning of February, possibly a couple of weeks earlier than initially discussed with the physios. Wales' first Six Nations match is against Ireland on February 7th. Additionally, Webb has re-signed his national dual contract with Ospreys and the Welsh Rugby Union, choosing to stay with the team where he debuted in 2007, citing his desire to play for his country as a motivating factor.

On Tuesday morning, US border agents near Sumas, Washington, encountered two men, later identified as Jeffrey Laviolette and Nathan Hall, carrying backpacks containing 58lb of MDMA, or ecstasy, which they were attempting to smuggle from Canada to San Francisco. When ordered to halt, one man fired at the agents and fled, while Laviolette was immediately arrested. Hall, a Canadian citizen, was arrested the following morning in British Columbia. A third individual, Kali Henifin, and her boyfriend, Ryan Lambert, were also arrested; Henifin was allegedly planning to pick up the smugglers, and Lambert confessed to being paid to transport the drugs to San Francisco. The three in US custody face charges including conspiracy, drug possession, and distribution. The area where the incident occurred is known for drug and firearms smuggling.

The NSPCC's Childline service reported counseling over 4,500 children affected by online abuse in the past year, a significant increase from the approximately 2,400 cases in 2011-12. The actual number of children suffering from online abuse is believed to be much higher. Children as young as seven have been tormented and abused to the point of fearing school. Online trolls have caused widespread misery and humiliation among children, according to the charity. Dame Esther Rantzen, Childline's president, emphasized that bullying, particularly cyberbullying, can follow children home and become an inescapable persecution. She stressed the need for adults, parents, and teachers to intervene and protect children, as bullying does not resolve on its own and tends to worsen. Schools are urged to take the issue seriously, and children are encouraged to seek help. The report is being released during Anti-Bullying Week, coordinated by the Anti Bullying Alliance, which is collaborating with parents, schools, and other organizations to address the problem. A young person who contacted Childline described the emotional impact of online bullying, including being told to kill themselves, and the difficulty in dealing with the situation due to parental misunderstanding. Young people have provided advice on how to handle bullying.

The passage discusses a series of events and reactions related to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Here is a concise summary covering the core pieces of information:

1. The Israeli government, at the request of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, has postponed a vote on the construction of 492 new homes in the settlements of Ramat Shlomo and Ramot. This decision was made ahead of a speech by US Secretary of State John Kerry on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

2. The move comes after the US chose not to veto a UN Security Council resolution calling for an end to settlement construction, which infuriated Netanyahu. His spokesman claimed that the White House had helped draft the resolution and pushed for its passage, accusations the US State Department denied.

3. The resolution, which passed on Friday, states that settlements have no legal validity and are a major obstacle to peace. Israel rejected the resolution and responded by summoning ambassadors, recalling its own ambassadors, cutting aid, and cancelling a visit by Ukraine's prime minister.

4. The postponement of the vote was requested by Netanyahu's office to avoid further straining relations with Washington before Kerry's speech. A planning committee member explained that they are trying to avoid political voting in Jerusalem due to its sensitive status.

5. Kerry's speech is expected to address "misleading critiques" of the Obama administration by the Israeli government and lay out a vision for ending the Israel-Palestinian conflict.

6. Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas has said the UN resolution "paves the way" for an upcoming conference on Middle East peace in France on January 15, where he hopes a mechanism and timetable to end the occupation will be discussed.

The passage discusses the Queen's 90th birthday celebrations and Prince William's tribute to her. Key points include:

In a match between Cheltenham Town and West Ham United, the Premier League side secured a 2-0 victory. Aidan McNicholl, a 36-year-old hospital radiographer, was killed in a collision on the A5 at Cerrigydrudion when Andreas Werner, 46, from Leipzig, failed to notice him while turning his VW Transporter right. Imran Khawaja, a 27-year-old from Southall, West London, is a British jihadist who tried to re-enter the UK after participating in the conflict in Syria. Known online as Abu Daigham al-Britani, Khawaja was a member of Rayat al Tawheed, an Islamic State-affiliated group that included many British fighters. The group produced slick propaganda videos and appeals for donations, targeting young British Muslims. Khawaja was involved in these activities and even posted gruesome images, including one of him holding a bag containing a severed head. He attempted to sneak back into the UK last year, faking his own death in the process. Upon his return, he was arrested and is now facing a possible life sentence. Khawaja admitted to four offenses, and his cousin, Tahir Bhatti, who helped him return, has pleaded guilty to assisting an offender.

The passage discusses the transfer of Kayden Jackson, aged 22, from Wrexham to Barnsley. Sealed bottles, some leaking, have been washing up at Poldhu Cove on the Lizard and other nearby coves in Cornwall, posing a risk to wildlife. National Trust volunteers have been clearing them away. A crash on the A9 north of Berriedale in Caithness at around 14:00 resulted in one fatality and several minor injuries. The road was subsequently closed with diversions via the A897 Helmsdale to Melvich road. Police Scotland is conducting ongoing inquiries into the incident.

The passage discusses Dorian Dervite, a 28-year-old French centre-back who contributed to Bolton Wanderers' second-place finish in League One and subsequent promotion. The passage details a dispute between the Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) and the Labour party over their approaches to Brexit amendments. The passage discusses the low priority of defense in the UK's election, with public and political focus influenced by combat fatigue from past interventions and pressing concerns like the economy and healthcare. The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Barcelona's signing of Neymar, including the club's insistence that they did not commit any offense, the resignation of former president Sandro Rosell amid accusations of misappropriation of funds, and the ongoing investigation into the transfer. The passage discusses a tragic car accident where Michael Luciw, a 27-year-old father, was killed when the van he was traveling in was hit by a Mazda Premacy driven by Albert Kenneth Newman, who was driving on the wrong side of the motorway. Luciw's family is advocating for retired individuals to undergo regular driving tests, citing concerns over age-related declines in reaction time. The passage discusses concerns over the safety of mesh implants used to treat incontinence in women, with some experiencing severe side effects. Two members of the original review group resigned in protest over the final report, which they felt was diluted. An independent expert, Professor Alison Britton, will review the report's conclusions and the process by which it was produced. The report recommends that mesh procedures should not be routinely offered to women with pelvic organ prolapse and suggests a range of treatments with informed choice for patients. It also calls for mandatory reporting of adverse events. Despite calls for a ban, the Scottish government will continue to implement the recommendations, as it lacks the authority to ban the procedures outright. The chairwoman of the independent review, Tracey Gillies, apologized for not unifying all panel members and acknowledged the difficulty of her task. Two patients, Olive McIlroy and Elaine Holmes, and a consultant resigned from the review group over issues with the final report. Over 20,000 women in Scotland have received mesh implants, with over 400 currently in legal action due to complications.

Here's a concise summary of the passage:

In the equestrian event, Jung triumphed riding Sam, a last-minute substitute due to Fischertakinou's infection. Andy Murray, the British tennis player, won his third-round match at Wimbledon against Fabio Fognini in four sets, finishing at 20:57 BST after two hours and 39 minutes. Fognini, the 29th seed, had five set points to force a fifth set, but Murray won five games in a row to secure his place in the last 16 for the 11th time. On October 6, 2014, a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven led to a police investigation which revealed that the bar was serving alcohol past legal hours, as late as 04:49 BST. The bar's licensee, Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged for allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. Mike Nesbitt, during the launch of his party's manifesto, emphasized the importance of partnership over domination. The Ulster Unionists aim to make the election a referendum on the handling of the Renewable Heat Incentive scandal, but attention has shifted to Nesbitt's comments, particularly after senior party member Danny Kennedy distanced himself from them. The Justice Minister, Claire Sugden, has confirmed that a motion will be presented to the assembly to approve pardons for gay and bisexual men convicted of abolished sexual offenses, aligning Northern Ireland with England and Wales. Dubbed 'Turing's Law', after WWII code-breaker Alan Turing, the law will offer posthumous pardons and allow living individuals to apply for pardons. The motion aims to ensure equal treatment and rectify past wrongs, with arrangements to be implemented promptly.

The passage highlights Laura Muir's achievement in setting a new Scottish record in the 1500m race with a time of 4:19.12, finishing second behind Kenyan Faith Kipyegon. This performance surpassed Yvonne Murray's 1994 record and placed Muir second on the British all-time list, behind Zola Budd. Muir, who previously finished fifth in the World Championships, now holds Scottish records in both the 1500m and mile races. Muir's next goal is to secure a place in the Olympics for Great Britain at the British trials in June. She began her season with an 800m victory in France and plans to compete in a 1500m race in Stockholm the following week. Despite her demanding veterinary studies, Muir has managed to excel in her athletic career.

The passage discusses the case of Alexander Litvinenko, who was poisoned with polonium-210 in London in 2006, leading to his death. Richard Horwell QC, representing the Met Police, suggests that the Russian state was likely involved in the plot to kill Litvinenko, as the two main suspects, Dmitry Kovtun and Andrei Lugovoi, had no personal motive. Horwell argues that the use of polonium indicates Russian state participation, though he does not implicate President Vladimir Putin directly. Litvinenko, a defector to the UK who had accused the FSB of corruption and murder, was seen as a traitor by Russia and had publicly attacked Putin. The suspects left a trail of polonium, and their involvement in two poisoning attempts against Litvinenko is highlighted. The public risk from the polonium will never be fully known. Attempts to extradite Kovtun and Lugovoi from Russia have been unsuccessful.

The passage discusses the appointment of Steve Smith, aged 26, as the new captain of the Australian cricket team, succeeding Michael Clarke who retired after the Ashes defeat by England. Accord Healthcare is repurposing the former Sanofi drug manufacturing site in Fawdon, which closed in 2015 resulting in 450 job losses. Summary: Richard Ellis, Ciaran Monaghan, and Ewan Sutherland are leaving their positions at the local council. Ellis, who has served as the interim director of corporate governance and deputy chief executive, is leaving at the end of his contract. Monaghan, the head of the chief executive's office, and Sutherland, head of human resources and customer services, are departing under a voluntary redundancy and early retirement scheme. Stephen Flynn, leader of the opposition SNP group, attributes these departures to the council's struggles in retaining senior staff and anticipates more exits in the coming months. The council's chief executive, Angela Scott, expressed gratitude for their dedication and professionalism.

The passage discusses the decision of an English rider, likely referring to Peter Hickman given the context, to not continue road racing on the Hondas for the remainder of the year after a series of setbacks. The rider experienced a crash at the TT (Isle of Man Tourist Trophy) race, and the Fireblade bike faced significant mechanical issues. Initially, he announced his quitting of road racing but later clarified on Facebook that he is not entirely giving up on racing. He did not participate in the North West 200 due to his team-mate John McGuinness's crash during practice and will not compete in the upcoming Ulster Grand Prix. The rider described the TT as a disaster, with little enjoyment aside from racing the Mugen bike and walking his dog. He felt he was effectively a test rider due to the bike's issues and after testing at Cadwell, informed the team that the bike would not be competitive at the Ulster Grand Prix. The team decided to withdraw him from the event without directly informing him, which he accepted. The rider concludes by stating he has no unfinished business and is interested in racing in classic and unusual events.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) has won 19 out of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) and the first time since the end of military rule in 1999. This follows the APC's victory in the presidential poll, with Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on May 29th. The PDP's losses were particularly notable in key northern states and in Adamawa, affected by Boko Haram's insurgency, though it retained control of Rivers State and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The election in Imo state was declared inconclusive, and elections were not held in seven states. The APC's gains have relegated the PDP to a regional party, with the PDP failing to secure votes nationally. However, the APC did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari given the potential for militant groups to disrupt oil production. The elections were marred by violence in some areas, but overall were more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing democracy. The PDP will need to undergo a period of introspection and rebuild under new leadership, following 16 years in power and facing allegations of corruption and failure to address the insurgency in the north-east.

Here is a summary of the passage:

A US environmental group, Mighty, has accused Singapore-based agricultural commodities trader Olam and its main shareholder, Temasek, of turning a blind eye to unsustainable palm oil trading practices that may contribute to the haze caused by fires in Indonesia. Olam, which buys 99% of its palm oil from third-party suppliers, denies the allegations and says it has a strict 'no burn-no peat-no deforestation' compliance policy. The company has released the names of its 14 suppliers after previously resisting calls to do so. Temasek, which is majority-owned by the Singapore government, also dismisses the allegations, stating that it fully supports no-burn policies for land clearance. The report highlights concerns about Olam's practices in Gabon, where it is accused of bulldozing rainforests to establish monoculture palm oil plantations. Olam denies these allegations, stating that its private-public partnerships in Gabon strive to be responsible and transparent. The palm oil industry globally has a troubled track record, with accusations of unfair and illegal labor practices, deforestation, and burning of plantations. Green groups and palm oil executives often find themselves at odds with one another, with NGOs accusing the industry of turning a blind eye to environmentally unfriendly practices, while palm oil executives claim it is an industry-wide problem and policing third-party suppliers is impossible. Activists say governments need to punish palm oil firms that don't comply with acceptable standards of protecting the environment, but changing the government mindset can be challenging, as many of these firms bring jobs and investment to rural areas.
On 27 August 2016, a restaurant started serving puppy platters following the introduction of a new law that permits dogs to dine at restaurants, provided they are in outdoor areas.

The passage discusses the injury and playing status of several players for an unspecified team, likely facing Derby County. The passage discusses the lifting of a ban on YouTube in Pakistan, which was imposed in 2012 due to the uploading of the controversial film "Innocence of Muslims." The ban was lifted after Google launched a Pakistan-specific version of YouTube. The Pakistan Telecommunication Authority (PTA) directed internet service providers to restore access to the platform. The Ministry of Information Technology stated that Google has provided a process for the PTA to request the blocking of offending material, which Google will restrict for users in Pakistan after review. However, YouTube clarified that government requests for content removal are not automatically granted and must comply with community guidelines. The terms of the agreement between Google and the government have been called into question by activists who seek transparency. Google recently launched local versions of YouTube for Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka.

The summary of the passage is as follows:

- Domenico Scala, head of FIFA's Ad-Hoc Electoral Committee, is Swiss-Italian, as is presidential candidate Gianni Infantino. Scala had excused himself from the 2015 elections due to sharing nationality with Swiss candidate Sepp Blatter.
- LFA boss Musa Bility threatens to take the case to the Court of Arbitration for Sport if Scala does not withdraw by Thursday, citing Article 7.4 of the Electoral Regulations regarding conflict of interest.

- Bility, who was denied participation in the elections after failing an eligibility check, has pledged his vote to Prince Ali and urges fellow Africans to do the same.
- The election, to replace long-standing president Sepp Blatter, will include candidates Jerome Champagne, Sheikh Salman, and Tokyo Sexwale, alongside Prince Ali and Infantino, and will be held in Zurich.

Two workers, Daniel Timbers, 29, and Barry Joy, 56, died in an explosion at Harford Attachments, a company in Spar Road that manufactures buckets for diggers. The incident, which occurred in the paint-spraying area around 09:00 BST on Monday, is believed to have been caused by a flashover explosion due to a build-up of toxic fumes and an ignition source, creating a fire-ball effect. The bodies were removed from the site on Tuesday afternoon. Forensic inquiries have made significant progress, and witness statements have been obtained. The Health and Safety Executive is also involved in gathering evidence, including electrical safety experts.

Summary: Tunisia avoided expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after apologizing to the Confederation of African Football (Caf) for complaints made during the 2015 tournament. Morocco's participation in the 2017 qualifiers was reinstated by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) after a ban was overturned. Morocco was initially punished for refusing to host the 2015 tournament over Ebola virus concerns, leading to a fine and a ban. The fine was later reduced, and Morocco is now preparing for future participation. Tunisia's conflict with Caf arose from a controversial penalty decision in their quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in 2015. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) did not accuse Caf of corruption but criticized the referee's selection. After a meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou, tensions were resolved, securing Tunisia's place in the 2017 qualifiers. Tunisia will face Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A, while Morocco will play against Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome in Group F. If Tunisia qualifies for the 2017 finals in Gabon, it will mark their thirteenth consecutive appearance, setting a new record.

The passage details a post-match charge resulting from a mass fracas during a game at Etihad Stadium, which Chelsea won 3-1. Key points include:

- Manchester City's Sergio Aguero and Fernandinho were sent off, with Aguero receiving a four-match ban for violent conduct and Fernandinho facing a three-match ban.
- Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas will not face further action.

- Both clubs have until 18:00 GMT on 8 December to respond to the charge.

The passage discusses a pilot program in Cwm Cynon and Neath areas focusing on patients whose family doctors suspect cancer but show no clear symptoms. This follows a visit by doctors to Denmark to study their diagnostic systems, which have improved cancer survival rates. The concern in Wales is that asymptomatic patients wait too long for diagnosis because they don't fit easily into any specific treatment pathway, leading to multiple referrals and tests over several weeks. The fear is that many patients start treatment when their cancer has progressed or is less treatable. Under the pilot, 40 doctors in Cwm Cymon who suspect something might refer patients to a diagnostic center at the Royal Glamorgan Hospital within seven days. The aim is to see and test about six patients a week on the same day. Currently, only 35% of patients with concerning symptoms receive a diagnosis in the Cwm Taf area. Doctors want to reach the majority of patients without such obvious symptoms sooner. A suspected clinic will be set up at Neath Port Talbot Hospital as part of another pilot by Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board. The trials were developed over 12 months since specialists returned from Aarhus, Denmark, which established diagnostic centers after concerns about lagging cancer survival rates. Dr. Gareth Davies, Director of the Wales Cancer Network, says the plan will ease doctor's minds and speed up the process. Gareth Jordan, a doctor in Aberdare, says the pilot could make a significant difference to patients' lives by allowing quicker diagnosis and treatment. If the Cwm Cynon pilot, which will run for six months, is successful, other local health boards will offer the same service in the following months.

England has won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, setting up their second largest victory over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. England's performance was praised by former captain Michael Vaughan, who described it as an "absolute hammering." Pakistan's spirit was said to be broken, and they only batted for 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. The third Test will be played at Edgbaston starting on 3 August.

The British and Irish Lions, led by head coach Warren Gatland, have named Rob Howley as interim coach for their New Zealand tour. Forwards coach Robin McBryde will take on head coach responsibilities for Wales for the third time, having led the team in 2009 and 2013. McBryde views this as an honor and an exciting opportunity. The Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) will appoint additional assistant coaches for the summer tour. WRU chief executive Martyn Phillips expects to confirm the full management team soon. WRU chairman Gareth Davies, also on the Lions' selection panel, believes the involvement of Welsh coaches in different environments will benefit Welsh rugby in the long term, with previous Lions experiences having invigorated coaches and players alike.

Hull City achieved their first league win since August, defeating Southampton 2-1, ending a six-game losing streak. Charlie Austin's early penalty put Southampton in the lead, but Hull's Robert Snodgrass, who came on as a substitute, scored and assisted Michael Dawson's goal within two minutes in the second half, turning the game around.
