Assistant Chief Constable Stephen Martin expressed his dismay over these mindless attacks on police and the community. The PSNI Newry & Mourne Facebook page appealed to parents to monitor their children's whereabouts and activities.

The passage discusses the legal dispute between American Apparel and its founder, Dov Charney, who was removed from his position due to employee complaints and allegations of misusing company funds. The company's board has filed documents in a San Francisco court, stating they do not anticipate Charney's return and providing evidence of his inappropriate emails to female employees and racially derogatory remarks. Charney's lawyer, Keith Fink, claims these statements are false and accuses the company of invading Charney's privacy. The company asserts that Charney's actions violated their sexual harassment and anti-discrimination policies, making it unlikely for any board to hire him. Recently, American Apparel obtained a restraining order against Charney, preventing him from making negative public statements about the company or attempting to remove board members.

The passage discusses an upcoming basketball game between Great Britain (GB) and Greece, which will be held at the Copper Box arena. This match is significant as it offers GB a chance for revenge after a previous loss to Greece in Patras, Greece, where the home team won 92-64. Three key players from the Greek team will be absent in this upcoming game. The event is highlighted by GB guard Teddy Okereafor, who expresses excitement about playing in London, particularly at the Copper Box, as it is his hometown. He emphasizes the importance of this level of competition in preparing the team for EuroBasket 2017. The game against Greece is GB's only home game before they participate in FIBA EuroBasket 2017, which begins in September in Istanbul, Turkey. Following the Greece match, GB's coach Joe Prunty will lead the team to a four-team tournament in Poland as their final warm-up before EuroBasket. The game will be broadcast on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app, with coverage from 17:30 to 19:30 BST.

The passage recounts the author's experience with the early iPhone, highlighting its significance in transforming technology and daily life. Initially skeptical, the author was pressured to feature the new Apple phone in a news piece, leading to a last-minute interview with Apple's marketing chief, Phil Schiller, who allowed a hands-on demonstration. The iPhone's impact is likened to the Model T Ford, emphasizing its role in putting powerful computers in the hands of over two billion people and disrupting various industries. The author contrasts photos taken a decade apart, one with a digital SLR camera and the other with an iPhone, showcasing the smartphone's improvement in photography and its ability to instantly share on social media. The text acknowledges that while phones had cameras and internet capabilities before 2007, Steve Jobs's vision for an intuitive user interface made the iPhone a game-changer, paving the way for the mobile connected era.

The RSPCA has confirmed that multiple cats in the Melton Mowbray area have died after ingesting antifreeze, with the latest victim being a seven-month-old cat named Meereen. The organization is unsure if the poisonings were intentional or accidental. Meereen's owner, Adria Pearce, reported finding the cat foaming at the mouth and attempting to vomit. Despite veterinary care, Meereen died three days later. The RSPCA is urging local residents to securely store pesticides and chemicals, especially as antifreeze use increases with the season, to prevent further incidents.

The passage discusses the apparent lack of public protest in Greece despite the Syriza government's agreement to implement further austerity and liberalisation measures as mandated by creditors. Greek resorts are experiencing a surge in visitors, with Athens airport expecting 25 million arrivals this year. The absence of street demonstrations could be due to the calm before the details of the bailout agreement are revealed, which is expected to include VAT increases, pension cuts, reductions in farm subsidies, and controversial privatisations. Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras' popularity remains high despite his failure to end fiscal austerity. The country is experiencing monetary austerity due to the partial closure of banks, which has led to a lack of lending and investment. The success of the new bailout will depend on Tsipras' ability to offer hope for future economic improvement, potentially requiring debt forgiveness from creditors.

Ross Kemp, known for his role as Grant Mitchell in EastEnders, is set to make a brief return to the show for the final episodes featuring Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Kemp agreed to reprise his role upon learning that his friend, Dame Barbara, would have her character killed off due to a return of cancer. The storyline will reunite the Mitchell brothers, Grant and Phil (played by Steve McFadden), for the last time with their mother. Grant Mitchell, a significant character in the soap's 30-year history, was involved in various dramatic storylines, including affairs and family conflicts. EastEnders' executive producer, Dominic Treadwell-Collins, anticipates that the reunion of the Mitchell brothers will showcase Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden's acting prowess as they face the loss of their mother.

Lance Corporal Trimaan "Harry" Dhillon stalked and murdered Alice Ruggles, a 24-year-old woman, in October. Her parents, Sue Hills and Clive Ruggles, were informed of her death by Northumbria Police. Dhillon had become obsessed with Alice and stalked her prior to the attack. Alice's mother, Dr. Hills, expressed guilt over reassuring Alice about the situation just two days before her death, while her sister warned that Dhillon might harm her. Despite the signs, the family did not realize the severity of the situation. In response to the tragedy, Alice's parents established the Alice Ruggles Trust to raise awareness about the dangers of stalking. Dhillon, 26, was convicted of murder and sentenced to a minimum of 22 years in prison.

The UK government has delayed its decision on the £18bn Hinkley Point C nuclear power plant project, just hours after French energy company EDF approved the funding. The project, which is being part-funded by Chinese investors, has faced criticism over potential escalating costs, environmental damage, and the involvement of foreign governments. EDF's CEO cancelled a trip to Hinkley Point following the government's announcement. The delay has been met with concern from the nuclear industry, which warns of potential energy supply issues and increased costs for dirtier power. Hinkley Point C is expected to provide 7% of the UK's electricity. The project has been troubled by doubts over EDF's financial capacity, with the company having to raise funds from its owners. An EDF board member resigned ahead of the investment approval vote, citing financial risks. Environmentalists argue that the project will be costly for British families and call for more investment in renewable energy. The decision to delay has been seen as a blow to the project, which has already faced numerous delays and uncertainties.

The passage discusses a new divorce application form in England and Wales that asks for the name of the third party involved in cases of adultery, a change that family lawyers warn may increase conflict. The Ministry of Justice, however, states there is no compulsion to provide this information. The form's update aims to simplify the legal process, particularly for those without legal advice, but it includes a prompt that may encourage naming the third party, against legal advice which suggests this is unnecessary and escalates conflict. If the third party is named, they become part of the court case, potentially delaying proceedings and increasing costs. Despite the small print advising against it, many may be inclined to name the third party. In divorce cases involving adultery, judges typically view unfavorably attempts to involve new partners in the proceedings. The form's design and instructions are defended by the Ministry of Justice as not obliging applicants to name the third party, emphasizing it as a relevant but optional part of divorce proceedings.

The passage discusses the forestry industry in Wales, highlighting a conflict between environmental policies favoring native, broadleaf species and the needs of the timber industry. Confor, an industry representative, warns that since 2001, 16,000 hectares of commercial forest have been lost and need replanting. The industry, worth over £450m annually to the Welsh economy, faces challenges such as inaccessibility of some forests and conflicts with local communities over timber transportation. The Welsh government seeks a balance through its Glastir scheme and Woodlands for Wales strategy, aiming to enhance landscapes, support industries, and improve the environment. However, Confor criticizes the focus on environmental aspects as more appealing and the bureaucratic nature of current policies, stating that only 90 hectares were planted last year against a target of 20,000 hectares annually to meet long-term goals.

A boy was severely injured after being hit in Coatbridge, leading to an emergency response at Bank Street near Langloan Primary School around 16:40. He was transported to Queen Elizabeth University Hospital in Glasgow with critical injuries.

The passage discusses the presentation of Ushakov medals by Russian Defence Attaché Capt Oleg Kornienko to veterans of the Arctic Convoys, including 91-year-old Charles Lewis. The Foreign Office initially prohibited the awarding of these foreign medals, citing rules against them if the act occurred over five years ago. However, an exception was made, and President Vladimir Putin presented the first medals in 2013. The Arctic Convoys were crucial in resupplying the Soviet Union during WWII, facing threats from German U-boats, harsh weather, and ice. Over 3,000 men died in this campaign, which Winston Churchill described as the "worst journey in the world." The Ushakov medal is given to sailors who have shown bravery in defending Russia or its interests. The ceremony was seen as a recognition long-awaited by the veterans and a symbol of gratitude from Russia for the support that helped defeat the Germans on the Eastern Front.

The HM Inspectorate of Probation reported delays in initiating unpaid work for offenders and excessive leniency for non-attendance, citing a case where an offender completed only 16 hours of work in 17 months. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the report's 15 recommendations for improvement. Unpaid work, ranging from 40 to 300 hours, is assigned for crimes like theft, drug offenses, and criminal damage. In 2014, 70,000 offenders were ordered to perform tasks such as garden maintenance and litter-picking. Inspectors reviewed 100 cases and interviewed 86 offenders across various probation divisions. Issues included poor organization, difficulty in managing offenders with chaotic lifestyles, and the challenge of enforcing sentences without resorting to imprisonment. The report highlighted some high-quality work and positive offender attitudes, but recommended improvements in work availability and alignment with offender circumstances. The chief inspector criticized the lack of focus on delivering and enforcing court sentences, calling for urgent action. The Ministry of Justice agreed with the recommendations and pledged to enhance rehabilitation effectiveness.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding a comedian who advocates for economic and political revolution to aid the less fortunate but lives in a luxurious home. This contradiction has led to accusations of hypocrisy, particularly when he was seen supporting a campaign against gentrification in London. During this event, a reporter questioned him about his own rent, to which he reacted negatively. The comedian has not responded to inquiries about potential legal action against a newspaper that criticized him but has addressed the hypocrisy claims on social media. In previous statements, he acknowledges his wealth and fame, asserting that he understands the need for personal and systemic change. He admits to past mistakes under the influence of capitalism and argues that his personal wealth does not diminish the validity of the issues he raises regarding economic disparity and ecological concerns.

The passage chronicles the life and scientific contributions of Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur known for his role in mapping the human genome and creating synthetic life. Initially criticized for turning the genome mapping project into a competitive race and for his outspokenness, Venter's work significantly accelerated the field of human genomics. After serving in the Vietnam War, which instilled in him a sense of urgency and a drive to become a doctor, Venter excelled in research at the US National Institute of Health. He pioneered a method to sequence genes by focusing on RNA, leading to faster gene sequencing. In 1995, he unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism, Haemophilus influenzae. Venter's most controversial move was founding Celera Genomics in 1998 to sequence the human genome in three years, competing with the public project and publishing results simultaneously in 2001. Despite criticism for his approach to data access, Venter's financial independence allowed him to pursue ambitious projects. In 2006, he established the J. Craig Venter Institute to create the first synthetic life form, Synthia, which was announced in 2010. Venter also embarked on a marine life collection project using his yacht, Sorcerer II, to sequence microbial genomes from the sea. The synthetic life breakthrough, while controversial, was hailed by Venter as potentially sparking a new industrial revolution by creating microbes that could help reduce our dependence on oil and mitigate environmental damage.

The passage discusses a survey conducted by England's School Food Trust, which found that 80% of children who eat school lunches have tried new foods at school that they hadn't tried at home. Half of the 1,000 parents surveyed reported that their children requested school-eaten foods to be prepared at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables among children, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were less favored. The research was initiated after a Mumsnet survey suggested some parents pack lunches due to concerns about their children's picky eating habits. School meals are seen as a way to encourage children to try new foods and diversify their diets. Mumsnet co-founder Carrie Longton noted that school environments can positively influence children's eating habits due to peer pressure and improved school meal options. School meals in England must adhere to strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary school children and slightly fewer secondary school students eating school lunches. In Scotland, around 46% of school children consume school lunches. The survey was conducted online among parents with at least one school-aged child between 4 and 17 years old.

The passage discusses the football career of Alvaro Morata, who at 23 years old, was playing for Spain at Euro 2016. He initially joined Juventus in 2014 after four seasons with Real Madrid, with his transfer including a clause that allowed Real Madrid to repurchase him for a reported fee of up to 30m euros (£23m). Morata had been a reported target for Arsenal and Chelsea. During his time at Juventus, he scored 27 goals over two seasons, contributing to the team's wins in two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata also played in consecutive Champions League finals, featuring as a substitute in Real Madrid's 2014 victory and scoring in Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. Standing at 6ft 3in, Morata began his career at Real Madrid, making his first team debut at 18 and scoring 10 goals for the La Liga side.

In August 2013, Wilson returned to Forest, a Championship team, from Celtic for a fee of £2.5m. After being let go in May, he is currently without a club. During his second tenure at Forest, the 30-year-old player made 51 appearances. Before joining Celtic, he had spent four seasons at the club. Wilson also has experience playing for Preston North End and Notts County. For more football transfer news, visit our specialized page. The core information includes Wilson's transfer history, his time at Forest, and his current status as a free agent.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by selling its loss-making food chain, Fresh & Easy, to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will transfer to the new business. Tesco will provide a loan of around £80m to the new business and will incur a cost of £150m to dispose of the Fresh & Easy brand. The deal includes the transfer of 200 stores across California, Nevada, and Arizona, with the remaining 50 stores expected to close. Tesco has the option to buy a stake in the business if Yucaipa turns it profitable. Ron Burkle, a billionaire investor, runs Yucaipa, which specializes in supermarket and restaurant businesses. This move comes after Tesco reported its first fall in annual profits in 20 years.

The passage discusses a martial artist who faced racial abuse initially. He shares his story of overcoming this adversity in an interview with BBC Sport's Nick Hope. The athlete, who briefly contemplated representing France, is now aiming to win a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. The text also invites readers interested in martial arts to refer to a special guide on how to get started.

The passage discusses the significant retreat of glaciers in the French Alps over the past four decades, as presented by Marie Gardent and colleagues at the American Geophysical Union (AGU) Fall Meeting. The research indicates that the ice fields, which covered about 375 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s, had shrunk to approximately 275 sq km by the late 2000s, marking an average loss of 26% over 40 years. This retreat mirrors findings in other Alpine sectors across Switzerland, Austria, Slovenia, Germany, France, and Italy. The study, based on map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, reveals that the southern sectors of the French Alps have experienced the greatest losses, with glaciers almost disappearing in the Belledonne Massif and retreating more than three times stronger in the Ecrins Massif compared to the Mont Blanc Massif. The researchers attribute the less pronounced retreat in the northern Alps to higher elevations and different climatic conditions, including more precipitation and cloud cover. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has also decreased in size, albeit less dramatically, from 31.5 sq km in the late 1960s/early 1970s to just over 30 sq km today.

Scotland's women's football team, having won all five of their qualifiers, is on the brink of securing a place in the European Championship finals. A victory against Iceland, who are also undefeated, could be decisive. Forward Jane Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, expresses her determination to avoid the heartbreak of previous playoff losses for major tournaments. With the best six of eight group runners-up qualifying automatically, Scotland is well-positioned to reach the finals in the Netherlands without needing a playoff. Evans highlights the impact of having multiple team members playing in top leagues abroad, which she believes benefits the national team. She also shares her experience of winning the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and the celebratory reception with the men's team, including interactions with notable players like Franck Ribery and Arjen Robben.

Stuart Campbell, a Scottish independence campaigner and blogger known for his 'Wings Over Scotland' blog, was arrested in England following a complaint from a woman in her 30s in south London. The woman alleged that she had been harassed over a two-year period, with the harassment taking place online. Campbell was released on bail until mid-September. He stated that the allegations concern tweets that are still publicly visible and insisted they were not threatening. Campbell accused the media of using innuendo to encourage speculation. He also mentioned that he would be posting less frequently on his blog due to circumstances beyond his control.

PETA is advocating for the replacement of Skegness's iconic Jolly Fisherman mascot with a more animal-friendly symbol, proposing a fish with the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice." PETA argues that the Jolly Fisherman promotes animal cruelty, referencing fishing and the suffering of sea creatures. However, Skegness's mayor, Carl Macey, believes there is little support for changing the mascot, which has been a beloved symbol since 1908 when it was created by the Great Northern Railway to promote the town. Macey maintains that the Jolly Fisherman is seen as happy and friendly, effectively promoting Skegness as a holiday destination. PETA's suggestion will be considered by the council, but the mayor suggests that without a perceived problem, there is no need to change the mascot.

Scotland defeated Georgia in a rugby match, with the Scots scoring six tries to Georgia's two. Georgia initially took the lead with a try by Vasil Lobzhanidze, but Scotland quickly responded with tries by Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime. Hamish Watson extended Scotland's lead after the break, and Hogg scored again following a counter-attack. Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia from a strong scrum, but Scotland maintained control of the game. The match saw Scotland dominate possession and territory, with Greig Laidlaw converting several tries and kicking penalties. Scotland's head coach, Vern Cotter, praised his team's performance, particularly in the first half, and noted improvements in their game management.

Widnes secured a victory over Castleford, with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge giving them a 14-6 lead at half-time. Paddy Flynn scored twice against his parent club, but additional tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (two), and Joe Mellor extended Widnes's lead to 38-12. Castleford responded with three quick tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn's third, but Widnes held on for the win. Mellor's try, capitalizing on Castleford's indecision on a short kick-off, contributed to a 26-point lead for Widnes. Despite Castleford's late surge, including tries from Patrick, Gale, and Flynn, Widnes's defense held firm. The win moved Widnes above Wakefield into seventh place, while Castleford stayed in sixth, one point ahead of Widnes. Castleford suffered their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old detainee at Guantanamo Bay since 2002, has been released after a US review panel determined he was not a significant threat to the US. Al-Odah, arrested in Pakistan on suspicion of ties to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, which he denies, had challenged his detention in the US Supreme Court. His release, which follows a July decision by Guantanamo's Periodic Review Board, will require him to spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. This is the first inmate release since May, when five Taliban detainees were exchanged for US Sgt Bowe Bergdahl. Al-Odah's departure reduces the Guantanamo detainee count to 148. The facility was opened in January 2002, and President Barack Obama has pledged to close it.

The passage details the observance of Anzac Day in London, which commemorates the first major battle involving Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One. Key points include:

- A dawn service at Hyde Park Corner was attended by thousands, followed by a parade and wreath-laying at the Cenotaph.
- An additional service was held at Westminster Abbey, concluding with the singing of the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia.
- The tradition of commemorating Anzac Day in London began in 1916 with a service attended by King George V.
- The event is significant for New Zealanders and Australians, honoring the sacrifices of their countrymen and women in all wars.
- Alexander Downer, the Australian high commissioner to the UK, addressed the crowd and laid a wreath at the dawn service.
- The parade at the Cenotaph involved veterans' associations, service personnel, and their families, with prayers read by schoolchildren and the anthems of all three countries sung.
- The Gallipoli campaign, one of the bloodiest of the war, aimed to force the Ottoman Empire out of the conflict.

The passage discusses the football player Clarkson, aged 30, who has rejoined St Mirren for a second spell and is anticipated to make his debut in the Championship match against Alloa. Despite scoring nine goals for Dundee in the previous season, he has mostly played as a substitute this term. Clarkson asserts his readiness and fitness, having maintained match fitness through playing for the U20s and rigorous training. With nearly 400 senior appearances and experience at clubs like Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers, he also has two Scotland caps and one international goal. St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, aims to gain confidence and climb the table with wins, starting with the upcoming game against Alloa, who are at the bottom.

The turkey firm Bernard Matthews was sold to food tycoon Ranjit Boparan, also known as the "chicken king," on Tuesday. Initially, there were concerns that the new owners would not assume the existing workers' pension scheme. However, after productive talks, Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed that all current agreements, including the pension scheme, would be honored under the new ownership. The Bernard Matthews final salary pension scheme, which was closed in 2004, has an alternative pension scheme for its members that is not affected by the takeover. The Boparan Private Office assured that the current pension arrangements would continue. During a meeting at the Great Witchingham headquarters, it was stated that the new owner aims to restore Bernard Matthews to its former profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and utilizing the company's spare capacity to process chicken in addition to turkeys.

The passage discusses a series of issues surrounding a new ferry service at Cowes, which has faced multiple problems since its launch on May 14, including breakdowns, grounding, suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency, and damage to cars. In response to these issues, the council leader, Dave Stewart, announced that the Cowes crossing will be free until July 2 to gather feedback and acknowledge the problems. The council has also ordered an audit review of the project. Local businesses, particularly Angie Booth's Valu-4-U shop, have suffered significant losses, and compensation for these losses is under discussion. Councillor Ian Ward mentioned that the ferry is a prototype and that initial problems, such as electrical issues and vehicle scraping, have been addressed. He also noted that issues with the ferry grounding have been resolved.

The House of Lords European Union Committee has released a report on the risks and opportunities for the UK fishing industry post-Brexit. The industry, which contributes only 0.5% to GDP and employs 12,000 people, is at risk of being marginalized in negotiations. The report warns that the UK may have to allow EU boats to fish in UK waters as part of a trade deal, as the majority of UK fish are exported to the EU, and the UK imports a significant amount of fish from EU states. The report suggests that elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy should be retained, and the UK should continue to base total allowable catches and quotas on scientific advice. The potential for four different fisheries management regimes in England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland is also a concern. However, some in the industry see Brexit as an opportunity to regain control over UK waters and become a leading fish-exporting nation.

Timothy Geaney, a teacher, admitted to taking or allowing images of young boys in erotic poses to be taken over a decade, leading to his conviction and placement on the sex offenders register. He was given a community payback order and mandated to participate in a program for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching register due to his actions being deemed fundamentally incompatible with the profession. The hearing concluded that his conduct, spanning from 2004 to 2014, showed a pattern of behavior rather than an isolated incident, with a strong likelihood of recurrence. Geaney, aged 69 at sentencing, was barred from re-registering for two years and did not attend the hearing.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

- A fire occurred on 2 March at a site in Duncan Street, causing disruptions to train services and travel delays.
- The Environment Agency (EA) has suspended Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited from accepting waste following the fire.
- The company was found to be "broadly compliant" with fire safety law by the fire service.
- Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, managed by Asset and Land Group, has until 7 August to appeal the EA's decision.
- Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS) visited the site nine times in the last 12 months.
- GMFRS raised concerns to the EA in February about the potential impact of a fire on residents, transport, and the environment.
- The EA decided to revoke the environmental permit for the site, effective 7 August, and the company must remove all waste.
- The cause of the fire remains undetermined.

The deputy foreign minister of Syria, Faisal al-Mekdad, stated that Syria is making its best effort to comply with the timetable for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing the recent deadline to hand over its entire stockpile. He reported that an attack by terrorist groups intercepted a shipment of weapons on its way to the Syrian coast. Mekdad criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's condemnation of the Syrian government's use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, calling it "absolutely unacceptable." The Syrian government denied reports of using barrel bombs against civilians and accused the US of supporting terrorist elements in the country. There are conflicting reports about the control of Aleppo's central prison, with the Syrian government denying that rebels have seized most of it, while the Syrian Observatory for Human Rights and activist groups claim that rebels now completely control the prison. Syria has about 1,300 tonnes of declared chemical weapons, and only 4% of the stockpile has left the country so far. The US defense secretary expressed concern about the delay in the UN-backed plan and called on Syria to fulfill its commitment. Russia, a key ally of Syria, has set a deadline for Damascus to complete the transfer of its chemical weapons to the coast for removal by ship by 1 March. The OPCW has admitted that security concerns have slowed down the destruction operation, but Mekdad stressed that Syria is committed to all its agreements and will implement all its obligations on time.

England has won the second Test against Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series. England declared at 589-8 and 173-1, setting up their second largest victory over Pakistan in terms of runs. Joe Root was named man of the match for his 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 off 48 balls in the second. He also took four catches and claimed a wicket. England's performance was praised by former captain Michael Vaughan, who described it as an "absolute hammering." Pakistan's spirit was said to be broken, and they only batted for 63 overs in the first innings and 70 in the second. Former England batsman Geoffrey Boycott believes England will win again and be too strong for Pakistan. The third Test at Edgbaston starts on 3 August.

The Older People's Commissioner for Wales, Sarah Rochira, is initiating a review to gather experiences of older people in residential care, aiming to develop recommendations for care providers and public bodies. The review will assess the quality of life in residential care, focusing on physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. Rochira emphasizes the importance of hearing from older people, their caregivers, and families to understand the impact of both good and poor care. The review's recommendations will aim to address variations in care quality across Wales and ensure better standards. However, Mario Kreft, the chair of Care Forum Wales, expresses disappointment that the advisory panel lacks representation from care home providers, which he believes hinders full sector engagement and partnership working.

The passage discusses the appointment of Paul Sheerin as the new manager at Aberdeen FC, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin, aged 39, has been the player-manager at Arbroath since 2010. Despite Arbroath's relegation to Scottish League Two after finishing last in League One in the 2013-14 season, Sheerin was chosen by Aberdeen's boss Derek McInnes following a thorough selection process. Aberdeen's CEO, Duncan Fraser, mentioned that Arbroath's chairman, John Christison, was understanding of Sheerin's decision to return to Aberdeen. Sheerin has played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, and he has a Scotland Under-21 cap from the mid-1990s. Notably, he led Arbroath to win the Scottish Third Division title and achieve promotion in 2011, marking the club's first national trophy in history.

The passage discusses the situation at Swansea City Football Club following the sacking of manager Bob Bradley. Assistant manager Alan Curtis and Paul Williams are set to manage the upcoming match against Bournemouth. The club is looking to appoint a new manager quickly, with Paul Clement being the preferred choice. Curtis expresses concern about the club's ability to recover if they are relegated, noting the strength of the Championship and the difficulty in retaining top players. He also reflects on Swansea's decline since the departure of Michael Laudrup in 2014, suggesting that the club has lost its way and the 'Swansea Way' of playing attractive football has been diluted. Despite this, Curtis believes the current squad has the potential to avoid relegation. The passage also highlights Swansea's remarkable rise from near bankruptcy and the brink of relegation out of the Football League to the Premier League, and the importance of staying in the top flight for the club and the region.

The passage chronicles the life and scientific contributions of Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur known for his role in mapping the human genome and creating synthetic life. Initially lacking academic focus, Venter's experiences during the Vietnam War inspired him to pursue medicine and research. At the US National Institute of Health, he recognized the need for faster gene decoding methods and pioneered a technique using RNA to identify active parts of the genome, significantly accelerating the process. This led to the founding of his private research institute, The Institute for Genomic Research, and later, Celera Genomics, which aimed to decode the human genetic code in three years, competing with the public project. Despite criticism for his approach to data access, Venter's work has been financially rewarding, allowing him to fund ambitious projects independently. In 2006, he established the J Craig Venter Institute to create the first synthetic life form, Synthia, which was achieved and published in Science. Venter also embarked on a marine life collection project using his yacht, Sorcerer II, to gather genetic material from ocean microbes. His synthetic life breakthrough, while controversial, holds potential for industrial revolution and environmental benefits, such as reducing oil dependency and carbon dioxide capture.

The Sutton Trust warns that many apprenticeships in England are of low quality and too short, with only 200,000 of the 520,000 starting each year rated at level three, equivalent to A-levels. The report, by the Boston Consulting Group, highlights that only 20% of employers in England offer apprenticeships, compared to 51% in Germany, and that 58% of apprenticeships since 2010 have been below level three, with three-quarters aimed at those over 25. The report calls for up to 300,000 new apprenticeship starts each year, with the majority at level three for at least three years. The Association of Colleges supports the call but notes the challenge of creating more places and the need to preserve respected level two apprenticeships in sectors like construction. The Department for Education states it is reforming apprenticeships to improve standards and responsiveness to employer needs.

The passage highlights the achievements of a British athlete, Storey, who finished over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska in a race held in Nottwil, Switzerland. She is looking forward to potentially winning her 17th title in the upcoming road race. Storey, aged 37, is aiming for more Paralympic success in the Rio de Janeiro Games next year. She holds the record as Britain's most decorated female Paralympian with 22 medals, including 11 golds, 8 silvers, and 3 bronzes, across cycling and swimming disciplines over six Paralympics. Notably, she secured four gold medals at the 2012 London Games and has accumulated 21 world titles across both sports. Storey started her career in swimming, earning six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, before transitioning to cycling in 2005.

Hereford United has been expelled from the Football Conference due to their failure to meet the deadline for paying football creditors, including former boss Martin Foyle, players, staff, and other clubs. The club's debt amounted to £148,000. Despite the Conference extending the payment deadline multiple times, the new owner, Tommy Agombar, did not meet the final deadline of June 12. As a result, Chester FC has been reinstated to the Conference Premier, and Hayes & Yeading will remain in Conference South. The situation is a result of Hereford's financial mismanagement and falling attendances since their relegation from the Football League in 2012. The efforts of the players in the final game of the season to keep the team in the Conference Premier are now nullified. Former Hereford boss Martin Foyle, now at Southport, has signed two players from the Bulls team, including keeper Dan Lloyd-Weston, who left due to unpaid wages. The club still owes over £70,000 to HM Revenue and Customs.

The passage discusses the career of a former Manchester City player, aged 30, who has decided to retire from international football. He earned 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009 and was part of the squad in two World Cups and two European Championships, although his playing time at Euro 2016 was limited to three minutes. The player, Milner, wishes the new manager, Sam Allardyce, and the team well for the future. He also holds the record for the most capped England Under-21 player with 46 caps, and his only international goal came in a 5-0 win over Moldova during the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers.

Christopher Hogwood, a pioneering conductor in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. His funeral will be private, with plans for a memorial service at a later date. Hogwood, who founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, directed the academy for 30 years across six continents and led numerous leading orchestras worldwide. Under his direction, the AAM produced over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notably, his 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah was ranked among the top 20 recordings of all time by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood's career included roles as a keyboard player and musicologist with the Academy of Saint Martin-in-the-Fields, a founder member of the Early Music Consort of London, and artistic director of the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society. He also taught at Harvard University, was an honorary professor of music at the University of Cambridge, and a professor-at-large at Cornell University. His influence extended to mentoring many musicians who now lead orchestras globally. Hogwood was remembered for his generosity, academic prowess, and dedication to historically informed music.

The passage discusses the struggles of a family from Northern Ireland who are trying to secure a place for their son in a special school. The boy, whose identity is protected, was removed from mainstream schooling in June due to his inability to cope. His parents requested a place at a special school, but all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area were at full capacity, leaving no clear timeline for a place to become available. The family was informed in September that the special needs school system was overwhelmed. Recently, they were told an additional classroom assistant was hired at a nearby special school, raising hopes their son could start there soon. However, the boy's mother fears other families will face the same issue due to the system's capacity issues. The Education Authority, while not commenting on individual cases, stated they are reviewing the need for special school places in Northern Ireland to ensure availability near where children reside, with efforts aimed at placements from 2016 onwards. The family's situation highlights the isolation and challenges faced by children with special needs and their families in the current educational system.

The passage discusses the situation involving Newport County AFC, Newport Gwent Dragons, and the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU) regarding the use of Rodney Parade stadium. Key points include:

- The WRU is attempting to take over Newport Gwent Dragons and views Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue.
- Newport County has a lease to use the stadium until 2023, with priority for fixtures if they remain in the Football League.
- Newport County's CEO, Kelly Morgan Foxall, asserts that their contract should be honored.
- A vote by Newport Rugby shareholders on the WRU's takeover is scheduled for May 9.
- Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirms that Newport County and Newport Squash Club are protected under their current agreements.
- The WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which conflicts with Football League rules.
- Newport County is currently two points above the League Two relegation zone with two games left, under caretaker manager Mike Flynn.
- Relegation to the National League would be a significant setback for the club and the city of Newport, according to Foxall.

The passage is a first-person account by an individual who experienced the civil war in Sierra Leone and later contributed to the fight against the Ebola virus. Here is a concise summary:

- The narrator had a normal family life before the civil war started in 1991.
- At 15, he was kidnapped by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) rebels, taken to the jungle, and forced to join their group.
- He endured brutal initiation rites, including having the RUF's initials cut into his chest, and witnessed extreme violence and atrocities.
- He managed to escape and ended up in Freetown, where he was caught pickpocketing and met Richard Cole, a preacher who founded Lifeline Nehemiah, a project aimed at rehabilitating former child soldiers.
- Cole encouraged the narrator to continue his education and instilled in him the belief that he could contribute to rebuilding the nation.
- When the Ebola crisis hit Sierra Leone in 2014, the narrator and his team considered it a common enemy and developed a clinic to treat suspected cases, saving many lives.
- They engaged in education, support, and collaboration with other agencies to combat the virus.
- The narrator reflects on his changed life, expressing regret for his past actions and a belief in the potential of young people to change the world.

The passage also includes statistics on Ebola deaths in Sierra Leone and other affected countries.

A public fundraising campaign, led by the Art Fund, successfully raised the necessary funds within a month to prevent the auction of about 80,000 works of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum. This was done to help pay off the pottery firm's pension debt. The collection, which charts a significant part of Britain's cultural development, will remain on display at the museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum. The successful outcome was attributed to the spirit of goodwill and determination shown during the negotiations. Had the funds not been raised, the collection risked being sold and scattered around the globe.

The passage discusses a potential deal involving the sale of a 20% stake in Billericay football club to an individual named Wright, with details yet to be finalized according to Dan Groves. Wright, a former non-league football player and runner-up in the 2011 I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here, is expected to become a club director. The club, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division, was recently acquired by millionaire Glenn Tamplin, who plans to invest £10,000 a week. Additionally, the club has signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United, Blackpool took the lead when Jamille Matt scored after Nathan Delfouneso's chip into the area. Colchester equalized when Kurtis Guthrie scored from close range after a goalmouth scramble from a corner. Both teams had chances to take the lead, with Blackpool's Tom Aldred missing a header and Colchester's Guthrie hitting the bar. The match ended in a 1-1 draw. Colchester finished the game with 10 men after Sean Murray was sent off for a bad tackle on Jim McAlister.

The passage discusses the proposed transformation of the disused Fawley power station, south of London, into a major attraction, potentially featuring the tallest chimney landmark south of The Shard. Developers, Fawley Waterside, envision it as the centerpiece of a "merchant city" development, part of a £1bn project that includes a marina, housing, and restaurants. The plan also entails fast ferry connections to Southampton and Portsmouth. The power station, operational since 1971, was decommissioned in 2013 after serving for over 40 years, capable of powering a million homes. The site, sold to Fawley Waterside in 2016, could see construction start in 2018 if the outline planning permission is granted later this year. The developers see the chimney as a signature piece of infrastructure, suggesting that repurposing it would be more cost-effective than constructing new landmarks like the i360 in Brighton or the Spinnaker Tower in Portsmouth. The power station, originally a 2,000 megawatt oil-fired facility fueled by a nearby Esso refinery, featured a 198-meter-high chimney and had 1,100 miles of cable laid within it.

Here is a summary of the passage:
- A 23-year-old British cyclist won a bronze medal at the Hong Kong championships, following Elinor Barker's silver in the women's scratch.
- In the men's team pursuit, Britain lost to Italy for the bronze medal.
- Joe Truman, Britain's sole rider in the men's keirin, was outclassed in his semi-final.
- The women's team pursuit squad finished fifth in the heats and did not make the bronze-medal ride.
- Chris Boardman praised Latham's final charge and timing in the race.
- Sir Chris Hoy noted that Latham's result was unexpected but a great achievement.
- Elinor Barker, an Olympic gold medallist, joined the women's team pursuit quartet, which included young riders with potential for improvement.
- Joanna Rowsell Shand commented on the team's progress and potential for the future.
- Katy Marchant, an Olympic bronze medallist, was eliminated from the women's sprint in the first round.
- Marchant expressed disappointment but focused on the process leading up to the Tokyo Olympics.

Ross Kemp, known for his role as Grant Mitchell in EastEnders, is set to make a brief return to the show for the final episodes featuring Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell. Kemp agreed to reprise his role upon learning that Peggy would be killed off due to her cancer returning. The storyline will reunite the Mitchell brothers for the last time with their mother, providing an opportunity to showcase emotional scenes between Ross Kemp and Steve McFadden, who plays Phil Mitchell. Grant Mitchell, an iconic character in the soap's 30-year history, will be involved in classic EastEnders episodes, including farewells to his mother and reunions with former loves and his brother.

In a match at Anfield, Sadio Mane's quick double exposed Tottenham's lackluster performance, with manager Mauricio Pochettino criticizing his team's desire and readiness to compete for the Premier League title. Pochettino acknowledged that a potential 12-point gap with Chelsea, if they win against Burnley, would be problematic. Spurs have struggled away from home, winning only twice since September, with losses to Chelsea and Manchester United, and draws against Arsenal and Manchester City. In 17 recent matches against top-six teams away from home, Spurs have won just once. Pochettino admitted that their first-half display indicated they were not ready to fight for the title. Former player Danny Murphy observed that Spurs' performance was uncharacteristically poor, especially in defense, and suggested they should have maintained their usual back three formation against top teams. Murphy noted a significant disparity in Spurs' home and away form, urging the team to improve swiftly.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) has won 19 out of 28 governor posts in recent elections, marking a significant defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), which has held power since the end of military rule in 1999. This follows the APC's victory in the presidential election, with Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on May 29. The PDP's losses include key northern states and Adamawa, affected by Boko Haram's insurgency, though it retained control of Rivers State and won eight governorships, mostly in the south-east. The APC's gains have reduced the PDP to a regional party, lacking a national spread of votes. However, the APC failed to win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, a concern for President-elect Buhari given the potential for militant groups to disrupt oil production. The elections were generally more peaceful than in previous years, indicating a maturing democracy, but were marred by violence in some areas, particularly in Rivers and other southern states. The PDP, facing allegations of corruption and criticism for its handling of the insurgency, will need to undergo a period of introspection and rebuild under new leadership.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival (HebCelt) in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, scheduled from 19 to 22 July, will feature an app that uses augmented reality to provide visitors with online information, videos, and band interviews from signs and posters at the site. This technology aims to enhance the festival experience and allow global interaction, with updates leading up to and during the event. Notable performers include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. Festival director Caroline Maclennan highlights the app as a means to access information, buy tickets, and experience the festival atmosphere remotely.

The UK government is terminating funding agreements with two Birmingham academies, Park View and Nansen Primary, following inadequate Ofsted ratings. The Park View Educational Trust, which runs these schools, may be removed. Two other schools, Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School, also rated inadequate, have been warned about losing funding unless issues are addressed. Concerns include poor management, failure to promote students' development, discrimination, and the imposition of a narrow, faith-based ideology. The government has outlined actions required by the schools to address these issues by 4 July. Parents and staff have criticized Ofsted's reports, accusing inspectors of bias and seeking an open meeting with the Education Secretary. Birmingham City Council will work with Saltley School, placed in special measures, to install a temporary governing board.

The passage discusses the trial of eye specialist Honey Rose, who is charged with gross negligence manslaughter in the death of Vincent Barker (Vinnie). Vinnie died in July 2012, months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich, where Rose allegedly failed to detect his swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. This oversight led to the undiagnosed build-up of fluid in his brain, increasing pressure and ultimately causing his death. The prosecution argues that Vinnie's death was preventable had Rose performed her duties competently. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court for coercing a woman into sexual activities with a man he found through an adult website and filming them. He also sent explicit clips to the victim's sister on Christmas Day. Despite denying the charges, Weatherhogg was convicted and placed on the sex offenders register. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. Weatherhogg was assessed as posing a moderate risk of re-offending. The victim felt "blackmailed" by Weatherhogg's actions.

In a cricket match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5 with significant contributions from Stuart Thompson (56), Gary Wilson (41 not out), and captain William Porterfield (39). However, this total was insufficient as Afghanistan reached 171-4 with two overs remaining, thanks to Samiullah Shenwari (56) and Mohammad Shahzad (47). The match began poorly for Ireland with the early dismissal of Paul Stirling for a duck. Thompson and Porterfield then stabilized the innings, and Wilson pushed the score to a competitive total. Afghanistan's strong opening partnership between Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai (27) ensured a smooth chase. Amir Hamza was the most successful bowler for Afghanistan with 2-23. Porterfield lamented that Ireland fell short of a potential high score and did not perform optimally with the ball. The team also faced the challenge of losing Boyd Rankin to a back injury for the T20s, though he is anticipated to return for the five ODIs starting on 15 March.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Barcelona's signing of Neymar, including the resignation of former president Sandro Rosell amid accusations of misappropriation of funds. Barcelona initially reported the transfer fee as £48.6m, but it was later alleged that the total cost, including additional fees and wages, was £106.8m. The club is under investigation for possible tax evasion related to the transfer, and in response, Barcelona made an additional tax payment of 13,550,830.56 euros, asserting that they are confident they originally met all fiscal obligations. The status of the case following this payment is uncertain. Neymar, since joining Barcelona, has scored seven goals in 18 league appearances and three in seven Champions League matches.

The passage discusses the murder investigation of David Miller and Hannah Witheridge, whose bodies were found on Koh Tao island in September. Metropolitan Police officers traveled to Thailand to assist local police, who have two Burmese suspects in custody. The UK detectives have finished their work in Thailand and will return to compile a report and update the victims' families. The suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, have allegedly confessed to the crimes but there have been reports of withdrawn confessions and mistreatment. They are charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery, facing possible death penalty if convicted. The UK Foreign Office had expressed concerns about the investigation, particularly regarding DNA evidence and suspect treatment. The involvement of UK police came after an agreement between the Thai Prime Minister and the UK's Prime Minister during a summit in Italy. Autopsies revealed that Miller died from drowning and a head injury, while Witheridge died from head wounds. Thai police claim DNA from Witheridge matched the suspects'.

The Scotland women's football team, having won all five of their qualifiers, is on the verge of securing a place in the European Championship finals. Forward Jane Evans, who plays for Bayern Munich, expresses her determination to avoid the heartbreak of missing out on major competitions after previous play-off losses. Scotland faces Iceland, ranked one place above them, in a crucial match that could decide the group's top spot. With the best six of eight group runners-up also qualifying, Scotland is in a strong position to reach the finals in the Netherlands without needing a play-off. Evans highlights the impact of having multiple team members playing in top leagues abroad, which she believes benefits the national team. She also shares her experience of winning the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich and the positive influence of training with top players.

Apple has enhanced its security measures by implementing two-step verification for iCloud, a process that requires users to enter a four-digit code, sent via text or the Find My iPhone app, in addition to their password when logging in from a new device. This update aims to prevent unauthorized access, such as the recent celebrity photo leaks, by blocking tools like Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, which hackers used to download iCloud data. However, the two-step verification remains an opt-in feature, leading some experts to suggest it should be the default setting. Apple's system also includes a 14-character recovery key for account access in case of lost devices, but this has raised concerns about potential loss or theft. Despite these issues, the new implementation is considered secure by Elcomsoft's CEO, Vladimir Katalov, who notes additional improvements like email notifications for backup downloads. Security expert Prof Alan Woodward advocates for two-factor authentication as a default across major tech companies, emphasizing its necessity in today's threat landscape. Apple plans to encourage users to adopt stronger security practices, focusing on awareness and password strength.

In the May election, UKIP, which emerged victorious, spent £2,956,737, closely followed by the Tories with £2,980,815. The Liberal Democrats (Lib Dems) spent £1,580,575 but lost all but one of their Members of the European Parliament (MEPs). Labour, which secured the second position, spent £1,027,339. These expenditures were incurred over the campaign period from 23 January to 22 May. UKIP's spending amounted to 68p per vote, Labour's to 26p, the Conservatives' to 79p, and the Lib Dems', who lost 11 of their 12 MEPs, to £1.45 per vote. The Green Party spent £534,249, or 43p per vote, while the Scottish National Party (SNP) spent £267,372. The total campaign spending by the six highest-spending parties was £9,347,087, with all except Labour exceeding their 2009 European election campaign expenditures.

The passage discusses two football player transfers to an unspecified team, referred to as "the Gulls," managed by Kevin Nicholson. Centre-back Myles Anderson, 27, has mutually agreed to terminate his contract with Barrow and will join the Gulls, potentially playing against his former club on February 18. Anderson has previously played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Nicholson describes Anderson as a leader with the stature and voice he has been seeking. The second player, 21-year-old striker Ruairi Keating, was recommended by ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams. Keating has played for Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps, and his transfer is pending international clearance. Nicholson notes Keating's youth, rawness, and hunger to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone and have won only one of their last six games.

The 10-year-old Irish-bred horse, Many Clouds, collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, having suffered from a severe pulmonary hemorrhage. This incident is rare and can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Many Clouds had previously shown symptoms of post-race ataxia but had no such symptoms on the day of his death. He had a history of winning significant races, including the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. His trainer, Oliver Sherwood, described him as the "horse of a lifetime." Despite previous overheating issues, the horse's death was attributed to the hemorrhage, which is uncommon in racing horses.

The passage describes the emotional farewells of veteran politicians in the Scottish Parliament ahead of the election on May 5. Tricia Marwick, the presiding officer, shed tears during the farewell speeches of Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond. Salmond, reflecting on his time in office, emphasized Scotland's diversity and strength, and critiqued the Scotland Bill for not fully delivering on promises made by unionist politicians. He also joked about competing with the Chancellor's UK budget and the Cheltenham racecourse for attention. McNeil warned that the Scottish Parliament could learn from Westminster's committee system and stressed the need for accountability and opposition. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also bid farewell, humorously recalling her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney.

The passage announces casting details for the live-action adaptation of Disney's Beauty and the Beast. Emma Thompson will portray Mrs. Potts, a role originally voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated film. Kevin Kline is cast as Maurice, Belle's father. The movie, directed by Bill Condon, is set for release in US cinemas on March 17, 2017. Emma Watson, known for her role in Harry Potter, is cast as Belle, with Dan Stevens as the Beast and Luke Evans as the antagonist Gaston. Josh Gad, who voiced Olaf in Frozen, will play LeFou. Filming is scheduled to begin at Shepperton Studios in May.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions on whether to bring charges against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough disaster, where 96 football fans died. The suspects include 15 under the Operation Resolve investigation into the disaster's causes and 8 under an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into the conduct of South Yorkshire Police and West Midlands Police post-disaster. The decisions will be revealed to victims' relatives at a meeting. Margaret Aspinall, whose son died in the disaster, expresses hope that this marks the end of the journey for Hillsborough justice and emphasizes the families' determination for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has informed local residents about a surge in incidents involving the throwing of packages over the prison walls. The prison is known for having issues with contraband, including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the problem and is reviewing measures to prevent contraband from entering prisons. A local resident has observed such activities four times in two weeks and attends meetings on how to handle the situation. While a former inmate suggests drones are used to deliver contraband, the Ministry denies evidence of this at Chelmsford. New laws now permit up to two years' imprisonment for those caught smuggling items into prisons.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, sustained serious head injuries in December when Brian Wright, 55, struck her with his car outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston. Wright claims he was blinded by the setting sun and did not see the red light, denying the charge of causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Blackburn, who was well-loved in her community, is now receiving residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse for the incident, acknowledging the impact it has had on Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing.

The passage discusses Scottish middle-distance runner Laura Muir's decision to prioritize her veterinary medicine studies over participating in the Commonwealth Games scheduled for April on Australia's Gold Coast. Muir, aged 24, recently placed fourth and sixth in the 1500m and 5,000m events at the World Athletics Championships. She explains that her exams in May conflict with the Commonwealth Games in April, making it impossible for her to join the Scotland team. Muir, who is set to return to university to complete her final year, expresses disappointment at missing the opportunity to run for Scotland but emphasizes the importance of her degree. She remains optimistic about her future in athletics, suggesting she could participate in at least two to three more Olympics. The World Indoor Championships in March are mentioned as a potential target for her, provided her studies allow. Muir also reflects on her performance in the 5,000m race, where she set a new outdoor personal best, expressing satisfaction with her run despite the tough competition.

The passage discusses the ongoing search for Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old who disappeared after a Christmas party in December 2000. The search is currently focused on a three-acre woodland site in Chapelizod, Dublin, and involves excavations that are expected to last several weeks. Earlier in the year, a team of detectives reviewed Deely's case, enhancing CCTV footage that showed him speaking to a man dressed in black outside his workplace, the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street. This man, who has not been identified, was also seen following Deely on Haddington Road later that night. The police have appealed for the man in the footage to come forward.

Juan Martin del Potro, currently ranked 165th due to past injury issues, defeated Stan Wawrinka in a 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 match at Wimbledon. Del Potro, a former US Open champion, is in the same half of the draw as Andy Murray. He will next face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young. Del Potro, who has undergone three wrist operations, expressed his joy and gratitude for the crowd's support. In other matches, Nick Kyrgios overcame a two sets to one deficit to beat Dustin Brown, and Feliciano Lopez, after losing the first two sets, defeated Fabio Fognini. Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga also secured victories in their matches.

The passage discusses the reinstatement of Morocco and Tunisia in the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations after facing potential bans. Morocco was banned for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola fears but had the ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS), with a reduced fine. Tunisia faced expulsion for complaints against the Confederation of African Football (CAF) regarding a controversial penalty decision in their 2015 quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea. The Tunisian Football Federation (FTF) apologized to CAF by the deadline, avoiding disqualification. Both countries are now preparing for the 2017 tournament, with Tunisia aiming for their first win since 2004 and potentially setting a record for consecutive Nations Cup appearances.

The passage chronicles the decline and storied history of the McLaren Formula 1 team. Once a dominant force with 182 grand prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, McLaren now struggles to achieve results beyond the fourth row of the grid. The team's downturn began in 2013 with chassis design issues, exacerbated by problems with the Honda power-unit despite having two world champions, Fernando Alonso and a teammate (not named in the passage), in their lineup. McLaren's past successes include a dominant 1988 season with Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost, and victories with Mika Hakkinen in 1998-99. The team has faced controversies, including a $100m fine for possessing Ferrari technical information in 2007 and a misleading incident involving Lewis Hamilton in 2009. McLaren's history is marked by cycles of triumph and decline, with Ron Dennis playing a pivotal role since the 1980s. Dennis asserts that McLaren will soon challenge Mercedes' dominance and return to championship-winning form, a belief that underpins Alonso's return to the team in 2015. Despite current struggles, McLaren's management is confident in their progress and Honda's future engine capabilities.

On October 6, 2014, a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven led to a police investigation which revealed that the bar had been serving alcohol past legal hours, as late as 04:49 BST. The bar's licensee, Colleen O'Neill, 43, and James Thomas, 44, both of Kevin Lynch Park, were charged for allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours. The judge, noting O'Neill's poor record, ordered the bar's closure for three months and imposed fines of £3,000 on O'Neill and £1,000 on Thomas. The defense acknowledged that Dungiven's licensing laws had not been strictly followed and that the bar had been operating improperly into the early morning.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for the most 3-pointers in a season, hitting eight 3-pointers in a game against the Portland Trail Blazers, bringing his total beyond the previous record of 272. Curry scored 45 points, contributing to the Golden State Warriors' 116-105 win and helping the team avoid a three-game losing streak. Klay Thompson supported with 26 points. Meanwhile, in another game, the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, impacting Miami's playoff chances. Pau Gasol led the Bulls with 16 points and 15 rebounds, while Derrick Rose scored 12 points.

youtube star and free-kick specialist bas van velzen surprised liverpool players mario balotelli, fabio borini, rickie lambert, and lazar markovic during a visit to melwood. the players initially thought van velzen was a competition winner there for a meet-and-greet and a free-kick lesson. however, they soon realized he was not an ordinary fan as he demonstrated his impressive skills. balotelli, lambert, and markovic watched as van velzen, who has gained fame on youtube for his free-kick abilities, scored a goal with a stand-in keeper unable to stop it. balotelli also managed to score a well-executed free-kick. van velzen expressed his delight at meeting the players and the joy of pretending to be an amateur before impressing them with his talent. he had one last surprise for balotelli, revealing a slogan associated with the player.

The passage discusses a study that suggests women diagnosed with breast cancer caused by the BRCA1 gene mutation, similar to Angelina Jolie's case, can significantly reduce their risk of dying from breast cancer by having their ovaries removed. The procedure, known as an oophorectomy, was found to cut the risk of breast cancer death by over 60% in women with a BRCA1 mutation. The study analyzed 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, finding that the 20-year survival rate was 77.4% for the group, with a notable 62% reduction in breast cancer death for BRCA1 carriers who had the oophorectomy. The protective effect was immediate and lasted 15 years. The study also noted a 65% reduction in death from all causes associated with oophorectomy. Women who had their ovaries removed within two years of diagnosis showed a 73% reduction in death compared to those who never underwent the procedure. The study's authors and experts in the field call for further research, particularly on BRCA2 carriers, and suggest that oophorectomy should be considered as part of the treatment discussion for BRCA mutation carriers with early-stage breast cancers. The passage also provides background information on BRCA gene mutations, their prevalence in the Ashkenazi Jewish population, and the increased risk of breast cancer for women with a significant family history of the disease.

here's a concise summary of the passage:

a married couple, derek lowe, 38, and tina lowe, 33, were killed on easter morning when an amtrak train hit them on the tracks in durham, north carolina. the train, the carolinian, was traveling from charlotte to new york city. none of the 166 passengers on the train were injured, although a man who fell ill during the delay did receive treatment. the lowes were pronounced dead at the scene. the train was delayed for about two hours and 45 minutes before continuing on its route. the couple may have lived in a homeless camp, according to a man who met them while collecting scrap metal. durham is located about 25 miles northwest of the train's next destination, raleigh. the trip from charlotte to new york city usually takes about 13 hours and 30 minutes.

the passage discusses the case of carlos toro , a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the medellin cartel who worked as an informant for the dea for 27 years . toro fled colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss and eventually came to the us , where he began working for the dea in exchange for the promise of us citizenship . he was one of the dea 's strongest assets , helping to carry out undercover stings around the world and aiding in the prosecution of high-profile figures such as carlos lehder and manuel noriega . however , despite his contributions , toro is now facing deportation after declining health forced him to retire , as he has not been granted us citizenship . the dea has refused to help him with his citizenship application , and toro is now living in the us illegally . he fears for his life if he is sent back to colombia and has been given $ 5,000 by a former colleague for an operation after the dea declined to help . toro remains in limbo while trying to secure a green card or passport and is unable to collect social security benefits until he does so .

The US body that regulates internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for potentially illegal actions related to the use of the new '.sucks' domain name. The company has been charging high fees, around $2,499 a year, for the registration of '.sucks' domains, targeting major brands and celebrities like Kevin Spacey and Taylor Swift, who have paid to have their names removed from these domains to protect their reputations. ICANN, after receiving complaints from an advisory panel, is now considering the actions of Vox Populi and has reached out to the US Federal Trade Commission and Canada's Office of Consumer Affairs for legal assessment. Vox Populi defends its business practices as being within ICANN rules and the law, stating that the '.sucks' domain is intended to facilitate company-critic interactions. However, the Intellectual Property Constituency, representing major companies, has labeled the scheme as predatory and coercive, urging ICANN to halt the rollout of the '.sucks' domain.

a woman has been arrested 27 years after her stillborn baby 's body was found in a sainsbury 's bag floating in a village pond . the mother , who has not been named , was arrested on suspicion of infanticide but the charge was dropped after she explained the baby was stillborn and she had concealed the pregnancy . the baby 's body was exhumed from his grave in norfolk last year and a dna sample led police to the mother . the baby was reburied at weasenham st peter church , norfolk . police have ruled out foul play and the woman remains on bail while the cps decide whether to charge her with failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial . the baby was originally buried without a name but a support group for parents of stillborn children raised the money for a new headstone giving his name as peter .

A taxi driver, Michael Young, has been ordered to pay compensation to a passenger, Kristopher Hicks, who sustained severe brain injuries after jumping out of the moving taxi. Young, mistakenly thinking Hicks was going to leave without paying, drove him back to the taxi rank against his will. When Hicks, then 23, objected, he was driven for nearly a mile, prompting him to jump from the vehicle at over 20mph. The incident left Hicks with brain injuries, epilepsy, and the need for constant care. His family took Young to the High Court, where Justice Edis ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages. The compensation amount, expected to be in the hundreds of thousands of pounds, is yet to be finalized. Hicks' lawyer, James Davies, stated that the settlement will help provide specialist rehabilitation and care. The judge also awarded Hicks an additional £250 for unlawful imprisonment. Both parties have been granted permission to appeal, and a future hearing will determine the exact compensation.

Here is a concise summary of the passage:

- Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night due to several storms that produced twisters.
- A tornado was spotted 6 miles northwest of Goddard, moving northeast and posing risks to other communities.
- Nighttime tornadoes are considered the most deadly and dangerous.
- Other tornado reports came from southwestern Kansas, with three sightings near Aetna.
- Kansas wasn't the only state affected; a tornado may have touched down in Potosi, Missouri, causing wind damage, flooding, and roof damage.
- More storms are expected on Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the Southern Great Lakes.

The passage is about the upcoming middleweight fight between Luke Rockhold and Lyoto Machida. Rockhold, aiming for his fourth consecutive win since his loss to Vitor Belfort, is confident in his ability to dominate Machida by being aggressive and cutting him off, likening himself to a bull and Machida to a matador. He believes Machida's avenue to win is small, especially on the ground, and plans to make him think about all aspects of his game. Rockhold respects Machida's skills and longevity in the sport but is determined to showcase his own style and win. On the other hand, Machida is also confident, believing that if he applies his style and technique, he can stop Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters see this fight as a potential path to a title opportunity.

The passage describes an incident where an aeroplane landed on a runway without its landing gear deployed, resulting in the aircraft skidding along the runway on its belly. This occurred at the Aero Acres Residential Airpark in Fort Pierce, Florida. The plane, an Aerostar, touched down with a bump, its propellers ricocheting off the ground as the wings bounced from the impact. The pilot re-engaged the engines and took off again, with the video maker noting damage to the propellers. Despite the collision with the runway, the pilot, Chris Georgaklis, aged 85, managed to fly 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely. The incident is attributed to human error or mechanical fault and is under investigation by the FAA. Georgaklis, who has flown for almost 50 years, was accompanied by his dog, Buddy, during the incident.
