the passage discusses the case of carlos toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the medellin cartel who worked as an informant for the dea for 27 years. toro fled colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss and eventually began working for the dea, providing information that led to the prosecution of high-profile figures such as carlos lehder and manuel noriega. he was promised us citizenship in exchange for his work but is now facing deportation after retiring due to declining health. toro's fears of being killed if returned to colombia are considered reasonable given his past involvement with the cartel. dea agent mike mcmanus, who worked with toro, has criticized the government's treatment of him and provided financial assistance for an operation. toro is currently in limbo, unable to collect social security benefits until he secures a green card or passport, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

A 14-year-old girl from Kosi Kalan, in Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district, India, set herself on fire after allegedly being gang-raped by five men from her village. She is currently in critical condition at Delhi's Safdarjung Hospital with 70% burns. The incident occurred when she went outside her house to relieve herself. Her family reportedly advised her to remain silent about the attack. The accused men have been arrested. This event has occurred amidst heightened sensitivity to sexual assault in India, following the banning of a documentary about the gang rape and murder of a student in Delhi, which led to widespread protests demanding better protection for women. The documentary detailed the brutal attack on 23-year-old Jyoti Singh, which sparked outrage globally and within India. Recent incidents, including the beating to death of an accused rapist by a mob, have further fueled public anger and calls for justice.

louis van gaal , manchester united 's manager , has stated that robin van persie will not be fit to play in the upcoming derby against manchester city , despite the player 's claims to the contrary . van gaal dreams of winning the derby to boost manchester united 's chances of finishing as high as second or third in the league , avoiding a champions league qualifying fixture . the team has been training in good spirits ahead of the match . van gaal also ruled out luke shaw 's return , as he does not consider him fit enough to play . the manager is looking forward to experiencing the derby atmosphere at old trafford for the first time since joining the club , acknowledging the strong support from manchester united fans .

Arsenal and Liverpool fans staged a protest against high ticket prices by leaving their seats empty for the first 10 minutes of a Premier League match at the Emirates Stadium. The protest was a response to the continuous rise in ticket prices, highlighted by the Premier League's £5.14 billion TV rights deal. Tickets for the game started at £64, among the highest in the league. Fans from both clubs, organized by groups like Arsenal's Black Scarf Movement and Liverpool's Spirit of Shankly and Spion Kop 1906, displayed banners inside and outside the stadium, with messages like "£5bn and what do we get? £64 a ticket" and "Football without fans is nothing." They criticized the commercialization of football and the lack of consideration for match-going fans, calling for tangible reductions in ticket prices to prevent losing a generation of supporters. Further protests were anticipated after the match.

a newborn baby named star reader was diagnosed with biliary atresia, a life-threatening liver condition, shortly after birth. her bile ducts were blocked, and after an unsuccessful operation to unblock them, she required a liver transplant. neither of her parents was a suitable match, but her maternal aunt, shanell reader, offered part of her liver and underwent the transplant surgery. star underwent the operation in november and has since made a good recovery, although she will require regular medical monitoring and anti-rejection medication for the rest of her life. the successful transplant was made possible by the selfless act of her aunt, who did not hesitate to help save her niece's life.

In a series of challenges organized by Audi, Chelsea football players Eden Hazard, Nathan Ake, Loic Remy, and Willian participated in various tests of skill. In the first round, Hazard and Ake defeated Remy and Willian 5-3 by kicking balls into the boot of a car. The second challenge, played on a makeshift tennis court with an Audi R8 V10 Plus acting as the net, was again won by Hazard and Ake, this time with a 6-0 victory. The final challenge, involving long-range shots at convertibles, was won by Remy and Willian. However, Willian accidentally broke a car's wing mirror during this round. Despite the mishap, the players continued the event, with Willian even getting to drive one of the Audis.

The passage details the sentencing of Robert Dellinger, a 54-year-old former Fortune 500 executive from New Hampshire, for a highway crash that resulted in the deaths of Amanda Murphy, her fiancé Jason Timmons, and their unborn child in December 2013. Dellinger, who was driving at over 100mph when he crossed the median and hit the couple's SUV, initially told investigators he was attempting suicide. However, during his sentencing, he claimed he was not suicidal. Dellinger pleaded guilty to negligent homicide and faces 12 to 24 years in prison. His defense attributes his actions to Ambien withdrawal, a psychiatric drug overdose, Prozac effects, and advanced multiple sclerosis symptoms. The victims' families are present in court, and Dellinger's wife testifies to his character and health struggles. A wrongful death lawsuit has been filed by Murphy's estate. Dellinger's career included high-level positions at PPG Industries, Sprint, Delphi, and General Electric.

Lacey Spears, a woman from Scottsville, Kentucky, was sentenced to 20 years to life in prison for the second-degree murder of her five-year-old son, Garnett-Paul Spears, whom she poisoned with salt. The boy's father, Chris Hill, expressed his anger and frustration on Facebook, wishing for her to face harsh conditions in prison. Spears showed no emotion during her sentencing. Prosecutors argued that Spears made her son ill due to a need for attention, while her lawyer described her as a hardworking single mother who loved her son unconditionally. Spears' lawyer plans to appeal the verdict, blaming the hospital for negligence. Garnett-Paul suffered through multiple hospitalizations and unnecessary procedures under his mother's care, which ultimately led to his death.

The passage discusses the delayed arrival of an improved influenza vaccine in Australia, which is a month later than expected. This delay is due to the inclusion of protection against two new strains of influenza, A strain H3N2 and B strain B/Phuket, which were responsible for a spike in flu-related deaths in Europe and the United States. The vaccine modification was necessary because the previous vaccine did not effectively combat these strains. High-risk groups, including the very young, very old, and most Indigenous Australians, will have access to free, government-funded flu shots starting April 20. Dr. Alan Hampson, chair of the Influenza Specialist Group, advises that everyone should get the vaccine, as it also provides protection against the H1N1 strain. He emphasizes that the modified vaccine should be a good match for the circulating strains and hopes it will prevent more deaths per capita than in the Northern Hemisphere. Dr. Hampson recommends booking flu shots now, considering the stock delay, and highlights the importance of protecting high-risk groups and their families. The vaccine to be used in the next Northern Winter will be the same as the one to be used in Australia over the next few weeks.

The caretakers of Abraham Lincoln's tomb are facing criticism and potential budget cuts that could affect the management of the historic site. National Geographic magazine recently critiqued the site, describing it as having "all the historical character of an office lobby." This comes at an awkward time for Illinois, known as the 'Land of Lincoln,' as the state faces a financial crisis and Gov. Bruce Rauner has proposed eliminating the state historic preservation agency that manages the tomb and other sites, instead rolling it into another department. Historian Adam Goodheart, in recounting the route of Lincoln's funeral train to Springfield, describes the tomb as "a disappointment" and reconstructed in "incongruous art deco style." The site's hours have been reduced, and it is staffed with fewer employees due to funding cuts. On the 150th anniversary of Lincoln's assassination, visitors found the tomb's iron door locked, despite signs indicating it should be open. Supporters of the site argue that the National Geographic portrayal was unfair, and the state historic preservation agency reports that the tomb is in "excellent physical condition" after recent repairs and renovations costing over $2.5 million. The tomb, designed by Vermont sculptor Larkin Mead and dedicated by President Ulysses S. Grant in 1874, has undergone reconstruction and renovation to provide public access to the interior burial chamber. Despite the criticism, some visitors, like William Sparks, find the site "absolutely gorgeous" and impressive.

The passage discusses the resurgence of 90s fashion trends and highlights some of the most questionable ones that should perhaps remain in the past. Key trends mentioned include:

1. **JNCO Jeans**: Known for their extremely wide legs, these jeans are making a comeback, to the dismay of many who remember them from the 90s rave scene.

2. **Bucket Hats**: Originally worn by fishermen and farmers, these hats became a fashion statement in the 90s and early 2000s, and are now being revived by celebrities like Rihanna.

3. **Camouflage Print**: Despite its military origins, this print has been a recurring trend in civilian fashion, favored by bands like Destiny's Child and recently worn by models like Jourdan Dunn.

4. **Extreme Fashion**: Taking trends to the extreme, such as wearing designer prints or double denim, was popularized by celebrities like Victoria Beckham, Britney Spears, and Justin Timberlake, and continues with stars like Kylie Jenner.

5. **UGG Boots**: These sheepskin boots were a celebrity favorite in the 2000s, and despite their lack of glamour, remain popular with off-duty actors and models like Kristen Bell.

6. **Daisy Dukes**: Tiny denim shorts, popularized by Jessica Simpson in the film "The Dukes of Hazzard," are still worn by stars like Miley Cyrus, albeit in slightly longer styles.

7. **Juicy Couture Tracksuits**: These velour tracksuits were a staple of the early 2000s, worn by celebrities like Nicole Richie and Paris Hilton, and have maintained their popularity with stars like Nicki Minaj.

8. **Colored Sunglasses**: Rainbow lenses were a 90s trend, worn by boy bands and pop stars, and are now seen on models like Cara Delevingne and reality stars like Kylie Jenner.

9. **Corsets as Outfits**: Once worn under clothing to shape the body, corsets became outerwear in the 90s, popularized by Victoria Beckham, and are now incorporated into red carpet wear by stars like Selena Gomez.

10. **Harem Trousers**: These loose, baggy pants with a cinched ankle were a trend championed by Kim Kardashian before she favored pencil skirts, and are still worn by supermodels like Elle Macpherson.

The passage highlights several trending stories from a busy week. Key events include the appearance of four rainbows over New York after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis. In China, the tradition of hiring exotic dancers for wakes is under scrutiny due to a crackdown on vice. Robert Downey Jr. (RDJ) showed irritation during a UK interview when questions turned to his private life. The Kardashians, specifically Kylie Jenner, sparked a new trend of lip plumping by sucking on jars, leading to the #KylieJennerChallenge. A 102-year-old woman, Alice Barker, revisited her past with the help of filmmakers. A school rejected a promposal that referenced bombs, with the student claiming racism. Ewan McGregor is set to play Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast', a casting choice generating social media buzz. Johnny Depp's transformation for 'Black Mass' is noted for its unrecognizability. A unique pregnancy announcement referenced 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air', and a military father photobombed his son's photo, earning praise for originality.

The passage discusses Serena Williams' 700th career victory at the Miami Open, which was celebrated with a large cake, following Andy Murray's 500th win celebration the day before. Williams won against Sabine Lisicki in three sets, advancing to the semi-finals. Her potential match-up with sister Venus was thwarted by Venus' loss to Carla Suarez Navarro. Williams, aiming to stay in the tournament, which is akin to a hometown event for her, will play against Simona Halep, who defeated Sloane Stephens. The text also mentions Williams' revenge for her 2013 Wimbledon loss to Lisicki.

Sabeen Mahmud, a Pakistani advocate for human rights, women's entrepreneurship, and free speech, was shot dead by two gunmen after locking up her cafe in Karachi. She had just finished leading a discussion on the disappearances and alleged mass abductions in Baluchistan, a topic that many in Pakistan want silenced. Despite receiving death threats in the past, Mahmud continued to speak out on controversial issues, making her a figurehead for humanism, love, and tolerance in Pakistan. Her cafe, The Second Floor (T2F), was a hub for secular wisdom and a safe space for young Pakistanis seeking freedom of thought. Her death has sparked grief and gratitude for her work across the country.

The passage details the plight of Mangu Ram, an 82-year-old Hindu traditional healer and refugee in Indian Kashmir, who has been denied citizenship rights for nearly 70 years. Ram and thousands of West Pakistan Refugees (WPRs) are hopeful for change after Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist party gained power in India's only Muslim-majority state. These refugees, despite never visiting Pakistan and living in Jammu, have been denied the right to own property, vote in state elections, and have been trapped in poverty due to their refugee status. The reluctance of state governments to grant full rights to these predominantly Hindu WPRs is attributed to fears of upsetting the demographic balance in the Muslim-majority state. With around 100,000 people classified as WPRs, most living in the Jammu region, the community has been affected by a pre-independence law that restricts citizenship to those born in the old undivided kingdom of Kashmir. The Bharatiya Janata Party's victory is expected to champion the cause of these refugees, offering hope for change. However, veteran activist Labha Ram Gandhi warns that the community is prepared to take action if their hopes are not realized. The passage also highlights the contrast between the prosperity of Kashmir as a state and the abject poverty of the WPR families, who are effectively second-class citizens due to discriminatory laws.

The passage discusses the situation of FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, who is considering an offer from Premier League leaders Chelsea. The offer, reportedly around £4 million, was confirmed by FC Tokyo's president, Naoki Ogane. Chelsea plans to loan Muto to partner club Vitesse Arnhem for the next season. However, Muto, aged 22, is interested in joining a club where he can play regularly and develop his potential. He is taking time to consider his options carefully, aiming to find a team that suits him and allows him to grow. Real Zaragoza's coach, Ranko Popovic, who gave Muto his debut in 2013, praises his potential, intelligence, and unique qualities, suggesting he could be successful at Chelsea. Chelsea's manager, Jose Mourinho, acknowledges knowing about Muto but refrains from discussing him further, respecting FC Tokyo. The club's transfer policy considers commercial interests, as evidenced by a £200 million sponsorship deal with Japanese company Yokohama Rubber. However, Mourinho emphasizes that financial considerations do not override the need for players to be good prospects or of high quality.

The passage discusses the recent change in policy by Australia to select their best players for the rugby team, regardless of whether they play overseas, highlighting the inclusion of Matt Giteau and Drew Mitchell. This move is contrasted with England's policy, under coach Stuart Lancaster, which does not allow the selection of players based overseas. The author argues that this policy is outdated and detrimental to England's chances in the World Cup, using examples of players like Steffon Armitage, Nick Abendanon, and Jonny Wilkinson, who have improved significantly since moving to French clubs. The author contends that the best players should be selected for the national team to ensure the best possible performance, and that the policy should not be dictated by the RFU or Premier Rugby. The passage concludes by praising Australia for their forward-thinking approach and suggesting England should follow suit.

The passage discusses the development of the Greenstone device by Open Garden, which is designed to enhance wireless mesh networks, particularly those used by the FireChat app. FireChat allows users to communicate without internet or mobile signals by utilizing multipeer connectivity frameworks in iOS and Android, creating a network where phones act as nodes to pass messages. Greenstone, an egg-shaped gadget, acts as a beacon or booster to extend the range of these messages beyond the typical 200ft limit. The device is useful in areas with limited connectivity, such as planes, underground, or during events with large crowds. It can hold up to 1,000 recent messages and has a one-year battery life. Greenstone is still in development and currently only works with FireChat at a range of about 20ft. Open Garden is collaborating with manufacturers to produce and sell the device.

Lillian Bustle, a burlesque performer from New Jersey, is working to eliminate the negativity associated with the word 'fat' by embracing it as a body-positive descriptor of her own physique. During a recent TED Talk, she explained that 'fat' is just another honest self-descriptor, akin to 'short' or 'wife', and should not be synonymous with 'ugly'. Lillian acknowledges that her perspective is not universally accepted, as evidenced by a 66% increase in size discrimination in the workplace over the past 30 years and the fact that many girls aged 11 to 17 wish to be thinner. However, studies show that increased exposure to body diversity leads to greater acceptance and preference for different body types. Lillian's burlesque performances aim to positively influence her audience's perceptions of fuller figures. Weighing 240lbs, Lillian found empowerment and body positivity through burlesque, which she began performing in 2012. Despite initial nerves about her body, she now feels confident and recommends finding a 'courage reference' to boost self-esteem. Her TED Talk, given in 2014 and posted on YouTube three weeks ago, has received nearly 38,000 views and mostly positive feedback, including messages of thanks and personal stories. Lillian believes that body positivity is gaining ground.

theo walcott, along with calum chambers, jack wilshere, mikel arteta, david ospina, mathieu flamini, and mesut ozil, has been featured in a photoshoot for lanvin, paris' oldest fashion house and arsenal's official tailor since 2013. the photo includes runway model olga sherer. walcott, who has spent much of the season on the bench, hopes to start in arsenal's upcoming match against hull. arsenal players will wear lanvin attire for the fa cup final against aston villa on may 30. walcott has been a substitute in 17 of arsenal's 33 premier league games this season.

A collection of movie props and puppets created by renowned make-up effects artist Rick Baker is set to be auctioned at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles and on propstore.com on May 29. The collection, from Baker's Cinovation studio, is estimated to be worth $746,100 and includes items from blockbuster films such as Men in Black, Batman Forever, and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. Notable items include an Alien Edgar Bug costume from Men in Black valued at $40,000, a Two-Face mask from Batman Forever at $1,500, and a Grinch costume from the Jim Carrey film listed at $8,000. The auction features over 400 items from more than 50 productions spanning Baker's 30-year career, which also includes work on films like An American Werewolf in London, Planet of the Apes, and Michael Jackson's Moonwalker.

the summary is as follows:

a seven-year-old british boy, carwyn scott-howell, died in the french alps during a skiing holiday with his family. he was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined child with a handsome smile. while skiing, he became separated from his mother and sister and fell over a 164ft drop after entering dense woodland. his mother, cari, desperately searched for him, and police found his body using footprints in the snow. the family, including his nine-year-old sister antonia and 19-year-old brother gerwyn, are devastated by the loss, which has left a vast void in their hearts. carwyn was a competent skier and snowboarder who had started skiing at age three. the family had been enjoying a happy ski holiday in flaine, france, before the tragedy. carwyn's body is ready to be repatriated, but his family remains in the alps. friends and classmates in wales are grieving his loss, and the community is rallying behind the scott-howells, who are well known for their award-winning farm shop. carwyn loved the mountains and helping on the farm where he grew up.

laura scurr , a 15-year-old girl from whitley bay , developed anorexia due to pressures to be a ` size zero ' , leading her to survive on just one piece of fruit a day and hide food from her parents . her condition worsened to the point where her body began to shut down , resulting in her collapse and subsequent hospitalization on a heart monitor . laura has since spoken out about the two-year battle with anorexia , detailing her extreme dieting methods and the impact of societal pressures to be thin . after receiving support from eating disorder organizations , laura is now in recovery and has a healthier body image , even making it to the semi-finals of miss teen gb , a competition that promotes positive experiences for young girls without size zero stereotypes . anorexia nervosa is a serious mental health condition characterized by an obsessive desire to maintain a low body weight , often through restrictive eating , excessive exercise , or purging . it commonly affects women around the age of 16 or 17 , although men can also suffer from it . symptoms include obsessive calorie counting , laxative abuse , and frequent weighing or body checking . if you suspect someone has anorexia , gently discuss your concerns and seek advice from eating disorder charities like beat . in the uk , around 725,000 people are estimated to have an eating disorder , with 10% suffering from anorexia . laura 's mother , sue , was shocked by her daughter 's condition and the societal pressures that contributed to it . after hospitalization , laura worked with eating disorder teams and child and adolescent mental health services to aid her recovery . her improved body image and confidence have allowed her to participate in the miss teen gb competition , which aims to promote positive experiences for young girls without perpetuating size zero stereotypes .

here is a summary of the passage:
raheem sterling, along with other liverpool players, unveiled the club's new home kit at anfield, designed by new balance, who recently signed a record-breaking £300 million four-year kit deal with the club. liverpool fans expect sterling to stay at the club this summer, despite his recent contract dispute. the new kit features an all-white branding and a new style of collar. the players also expressed their excitement for the upcoming fa cup semi-final against aston villa. liverpool legends robbie fowler and ian rush were also present at the kit launch. sterling had recently rejected a £100,000-a-week contract offer from liverpool, but the club is adamant that he will not be leaving this summer. the new kit is a tribute to the casualties of the hillsborough disaster in 1989, featuring a memorial flame and the number 96.

Researchers from the University of Manchester have created the largest single high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4% of the sky, as part of the Dark Energy Survey (DES). The map is the first in a series that will eventually cover one-eighth of the night sky, allowing a 3D view of dark matter. The goal is to map 12.5% of the sky over five years. The map shows clumps of dark matter, with red indicating more dark matter and blue indicating less. The map was created using data from the Dark Energy Camera, a 570-megapixel imaging device, and the Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile. The map will help astronomers study galaxy formation and the nature of dark energy, which is believed to be causing the universe's expansion to speed up. The DES has just completed its second year, and as scientists expand their search, they will be able to better test current cosmological theories by comparing the amounts of dark and visible matter. The team analyzed 130 million separate telescope images of galaxies to make the map, and the process is so complex that some of the world's largest supercomputers are needed to do it. The final map will cover an area 30 times larger than the current map.

Manchester United has made an official approach to sign PSV Eindhoven's 21-year-old star, Memphis Depay, as confirmed by the Dutch club's technical director. United's manager, Louis van Gaal, who previously included Depay in his 2014 World Cup squad for the Netherlands, is keen on making the winger one of his first signings of the summer. Depay, who has scored 20 goals in 26 league games this season, was previously targeted by Tottenham, whose £15 million offer was rejected by PSV. Now, Manchester United appears to be in the lead for Depay's signature, with interest also coming from clubs like Paris Saint-Germain. Depay's value has increased since Tottenham's bid, and PSV is now discussing significantly larger amounts of money. Depay's impressive season contributed to PSV's first Eredivisie title in seven years, which they secured with a 4-1 win over Heerenveen. The young player, known for his pace, dribbling skills, and powerful right-footed shots, has been compared to Dutch star Arjen Robben and is even suggested by some to have more potential than a young Cristiano Ronaldo.

chelsea 's young side took a commanding 3-1 lead back to west london after a strong showing in manchester to see off city . tammy abraham scored twice in the first half to put chelsea in the lead , with dominic solanke adding a third late on . city 's isaac buckley-ricketts had levelled the scores before half time . chelsea 's performance was praised , with abraham and solanke both impressing , while city 's defence struggled to cope with the visitors ' attack . chelsea 's jake clarke-salter and ola aina also had strong games , while city 's tosin adarabioyo and cameron humphreys-grant had their hands full against chelsea 's attack . chelsea will be hoping that abraham 's injury , which saw him substituted on 67 minutes , is not serious .

marco rubio, a presidential candidate, has stated that people are born with their sexual preference and that the decision on gay marriage should be made by state legislators rather than courts. he believes marriage should be between one man and one woman but would attend a same-sex wedding of a family member or staffer out of respect and love. rubio does not consider same-sex marriage a constitutional right but acknowledges that sexual preference is not a choice for most people. he compares his stance on gay marriage to his catholic belief that divorce is wrong, yet he would still love someone who is divorced. rubio, who recently announced his candidacy for president, has received significant financial support for his campaign.

pablo mandado and ilze zebolde are a couple who quit their jobs in manchester to cycle around the world with no set plans or agenda, aiming to discover different parts of the planet 'a pedal at a time'. they have been on the road for almost a year, covering nearly 7,000 miles across 16 countries. they manage to live on less than three euros each per day by relying on free accommodation, camping, and using hosting websites like couchsurfing and warmshowers. food is their main expense, costing 2.74 euros each per day. they started in london and have cycled through france, spain, portugal, italy, slovenia, croatia, bosnia and herzegovina, montenegro, albania, macedonia, greece, turkey, georgia, and armenia. they plan to continue into asia and across the pacific, aiming to cycle the length of the american continent in the coming years.

here is a summary of the passage:
a texas couple is suing premiere photos and its owner, james evans, for alleged racial discrimination during their 2012 wedding. the couple, represented by attorney cathy hale, claims that the photo booth provided by premiere photos printed racial slurs on the bottom of the pictures. the bride's sister informed the couple about the incident months after the wedding. when the groom contacted evans, he reportedly told them to sue him and did not apologize. the couple is suing under the texas deceptive trade practices act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. evans denies the allegations and claims there is no evidence linking his company to the offensive caption. mediation is scheduled, but if no agreement is reached, the case will go to trial in july. the couple's main demand is an apology.

Here is a summary of the passage:

- Mike Brown, England's full-back, is uncertain about his return to play after a recent concussion, opting for a cautious approach in his recovery.
- His decision is influenced by cases like George North, advised not to play this season after four quick concussions, and Johnny Sexton's 12-week stand-down earlier.
- Brown experienced symptoms after the France game, including a headache, prompting a cautious stance to avoid extended absences like Sexton or Geoff Parling.
- Increased awareness of concussion symptoms, partly due to World Rugby online modules, helped Brown recognize his condition before the Ireland game.
- Brown was previously knocked out during England's victory over Italy in the RBS 6 Nations, affecting his availability for subsequent matches.
- He emphasizes the importance of recognizing symptoms and not risking long-term health, even in crucial games, advocating for teammates to do the same.
- Brown's experience underscores the growing emphasis on player safety and concussion management in rugby.

The passage discusses a decline in sexual frequency among britons, which has been linked to the rise of the internet and increased smartphone use. According to professor David Spiegelhalter, a statistician at Cambridge University, the average heterosexual couple now has sex three times a month, down from four times in 2000 and five times in 1990. The integration of public and private lives due to constant connectivity, such as checking emails, has reduced quiet, intimate time. Spiegelhalter suggests that technological advancements have made lives busier, eroding the boundaries between home, work, and the outside world, leaving less time for partners. Catherine Mercer, a researcher on the British National Survey, adds that competing demands and late-night work emails can push sex down the list of priorities, making it difficult to focus solely on one's partner.

The passage discusses the dramatic fall in popularity and value of Tibetan Mastiffs in China, leading to their mistreatment and slaughter. Previously, these dogs, known for their size and loyalty, were status symbols and could fetch prices up to £1.2 million each as gifts to influence officials. However, due to China's anti-corruption crackdown and bans on owning dogs over 50 kg in major cities, the breed's popularity has plummeted. This has resulted in breeders and owners sending the dogs to slaughterhouses, where their meat is used for cheap hotpots and their skin for leather. The collapse of the mastiff market was highlighted when animal welfare workers rescued a group of these dogs from a slaughterhouse-bound truck, finding many already dead or in poor health. The passage also mentions the negative impact of cross-breeding on the breed's quality and the realization that Tibetan Mastiffs are not suitable for urban living.

The passage details a survey conducted in Paris, revealing that every woman polled reported experiencing sexual harassment on public transport, with half of these incidents occurring before the age of 18. The harassment encompasses a spectrum from verbal abuse to physical assaults. This pervasive issue has led to a significant proportion of women, six out of ten, feeling fearful of attack while using public transport, in contrast to three out of ten men. The consequences of this harassment include women altering their daily routines to avoid confrontation, thereby restricting their freedom and effectively excluding them from the public sphere. The findings have prompted calls for a campaign to address and reduce sexist and threatening behavior on buses and trains, emphasizing the need for women to feel safe and not threatened in public spaces. Advocates highlight the importance of educating women about the illegality and unacceptability of such harassment, as well as the need to hold aggressors accountable and engage witnesses.

Leeds-based Direct Line is conducting a competition called #EverydayFix, where they asked groups to design products addressing common daily problems, based on a survey of 2,000 people. The top issues included inability to sleep, losing keys, and traffic. Three prototypes made the shortlist: 'Snooze', an alarm clock that silences phone notifications for better sleep; 'Forget Me Lock', a device indicating if the door is locked; and 'Nipper', a tiny charger using household batteries. People can vote for their favorite on Twitter, and the winner will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign for development. Other designs not making the cut included a smart helmet for cyclists, a parking pin, and an app for forwarding messages when a phone dies.

Vera Baird, the Police and Crime Commissioner for Northumbria, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to Victims First Northumbria, a charity she directs which supports crime victims in her area. Sitting on the charity's board alongside her is Northumbria's Chief Constable, Sue Sim. Critics argue that this constitutes a conflict of interest and an inappropriate use of public money. Despite the criticism, Baird defends her decision, stating that all Ministry of Justice procedures were followed. The Ministry of Justice will investigate to determine if any conflict of interest rules were breached. This situation has been likened to "a soap opera" by Keith Vaz, the Labour chairman of the Home Affairs Committee, who also questions the wisdom of allowing Police and Crime Commissioners to allocate public funds to charities. Baird and Sim's working relationship is noted, with Baird praising Sim's passion and enthusiasm. Sim, who previously faced an investigation into alleged workplace bullying, is set to retire in June.

In a shocking case, three individuals have been sentenced to prison and two more are awaiting sentencing for their involvement in a brutal assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, in Philadelphia. The group, referred to as the 'Tattoo Terrorists', was led by 21-year-old Corry 'Corey' Campbell, who believed Valecce had hurt his cat and stolen from him. Valecce, an unemployed drug addict staying in Campbell's mother's basement, was beaten, tied to a chair, and forcibly tattooed over a period of three days. The tattoos included offensive symbols and words. Valecce managed to escape and contact the police. Campbell and his accomplice Carl Halin, both 18, were sentenced to 20 years in prison, while Campbell's girlfriend, Sandra Ng, 19, received 23 months. Another man, David Harrison, is awaiting sentencing, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, is awaiting trial. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but suffers from lasting trauma.
